content: Según la funcionaria, la comunicación fue abierta, franca, amable, respetuosa y recíproca. Además, se mostró optimista por lo que puede pasar en adelante ...
resumen: La ministra encargada de Comercio, Industria y Turismo, Cielo Rusinque, se reunió con el representante Comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, en Washington. La funcionaria informó que la comunicación fue abierta, franca, amable, respetuosa y recíproca, y se mostró optimista. Colombia espera la eliminación del arancel general del 10% impuesto por Estados Unidos a las exportaciones colombianas. La reunión también abordó el arancel del 25% aplicado al acero y al aluminio y a las manufacturas elaboradas con estos insumos, así como al arancel general del 10% que afecta las exportaciones de flores, café, banano, aguacate y confecciones, entre otros productos. Se refirieron a la necesidad de buscar acuerdos que eliminen barreras arancelarias y no arancelarias. Colombia insistió en avanzar en la admisibilidad sanitaria de las pasifloras, carnes de bovino y de pollo, y mejoramiento de condiciones para aguacate y arándanos. Durante la reunión, la ministra Rusinque expresó el interés de Colombia por exportar cannabis para usos medicinales e industriales a Estados Unidos. El encuentro se dio unas horas después de que se conoció que el Gobierno colombiano presentaría una propuesta que buscará aplazar la implementación de una normativa que modifica los estándares de certificación para vehículos importados. Dicha medida podría impactar un comercio bilateral valorado en USD700 millones anuales. El representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, expresó duras críticas hacia la decisión colombiana por medio de una carta dirigida a la ministra encargada Rusinque.

content: Washington, 24 abr (EFE).- Estados Unidos y Colombia mantuvieron este jueves en Washington conversaciones “positivas” en busca de un acuerdo sobre las recientes medidas arancelarias impuestas por el ...
resumen: Estados Unidos y Colombia mantuvieron este jueves en Washington conversaciones “positivas” en busca de un acuerdo sobre las recientes medidas arancelarias impuestas por el gobierno del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump. La ministra de Comercio, Industria y Turismo de Colombia, Cielo Rusinque Urrego, y el embajador de Colombia en Estados Unidos, Daniel García-Peña, dialogaron hoy con el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, sobre los aranceles de 10 % y 25 % impuestos a las importaciones del país suramericano. El encuentro se centró en buscar acuerdos mutuos que eliminen las barreras arancelarias entre los dos países. El Gobierno Trump implantó aranceles del 25 % aplicado al acero y al aluminio y a las manufacturas elaboradas con estos insumos; así como al arancel general del 10 %, que afecta las exportaciones de flores, café, banano, aguacate y confecciones, entre otros productos colombianos. La reunión con Greer fue “abierta, franca, amable, respetuosa y recíproca”. Colombia insistió en avanzar en la aprobación sanitaria de las pasifloras, carnes de bovino y de pollo, así como el mejoramiento de las condiciones para sus exportaciones de aguacate y arándanos. Rusinque Urrego expresó el interés de Colombia por exportar hacia EE.UU. cannabis para usos medicinales e industriales. Las conversaciones continuarán la próxima semana en Colombia cuando Daniel Watson, representante adjunto para el hemisferio occidental de la Oficina del Representante Comercial, visite Bogotá.

title: How Trump tariffs could upend California farms, wine and ports - (Published 8 hour(s), 4 minute(s) ago)
content: From higher costs to export worries, California’s agricultural and wine industries face many possible tariff effects. But some hope for opportunity.
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s on-again, off-again tariffs are putting many California businesses, jobs and the state budget at risk, affecting long-term relationships with trading partners and an intricate web of ecosystems and supply chains.

The Port of Los Angeles and the Port of Long Beach saw first-quarter increases in imports, but declines in exports, year over year. Gene Seroka, executive director for the Port of Los Angeles, attributed the higher volume of cargo being moved to “front-loading as a hedge against tariffs.” He said his port saw year-over-year declines in exports for the fourth month in a row, “raising concerns for our (agriculture) and manufacturing partners as counter-tariffs on exports begin to take effect.” Seroka predicted a slowdown in cargo movement beginning in May, and expects a 10% drop in volume from July until next year.

On April 9, Trump raised his tariff on China to 145%, although he later exempted certain electronics. China responded on April 12 with 125% tariffs on U.S. products. Chinese goods represent 40% of the imports that pass through the Port of Los Angeles, Seroka said. A decline in volume will affect port jobs. More than 1.5 million jobs are tied to the two Southern California ports.

A wine merchant in Walnut Creek who sells mostly European wines — on which the president has threatened 200% tariffs — said he’s going to have to make adjustments, like carrying more California wines, or consider closing up shop. Igor Ivanov, owner of wine shop Vinous Reverie, said the tariff issues are just the latest of the wine industry’s woes.

Natalie Collins, president of the California Association of Winegrape Growers, said tariffs on competing wines could help local wine growers. Bruce Lundquist, co-founder of Rack & Riddle, said so far Healdsburg-based Rack & Riddle is OK. Lundquist worries about tariff uncertainty dragging on, say through next year.

The U.S. wine industry grapples with tariffs: $86 billion in annual sales, U.S. Census Bureau data said. California exported $1.3 billion worth of wine in 2022, per the California Department of Food and Agriculture. 95% of U.S. wine exports come from California, says Gino DiCaro, spokesperson for the Wine Institute. 35% of exports go to Canada.

California recently became the first state to sue the Trump administration over tariffs. Gov. Gavin Newsom said the tariffs’ trade and geopolitical effects are “outsized,” while Attorney General Rob Bonta said the president bypassed the power of Congress to tax and regulate commerce by declaring a national emergency. California’s lawsuit seeks to pause the tariffs immediately.

One medium-size winery in St. Helena told U.S. Rep. Mike Thompson’s staff that since the tariffs Trump imposed during his first term, it has lost 90% of its business with China and is no longer seeking to sell there.

Daniel Sumner, economics professor and director of the University of California Agricultural Issues Center at UC Davis, said “the uncertainty itself has had damage, even though we (may not) get the tariffs.”

Ryan Talley is vice president of Talley Farms in Arroyo Grande. Talley said his medium-size farm is still able to sell spinach to Canada, but he’s concerned about being able to sell bell peppers to the country. He hopes the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement will protect those sales — but Trump has threatened tariffs on Canada and Mexico a few times. Talley Farms’ other crops — including cabbage, kale, lettuce and corn — are distributed domestically but are highly perishable. Talley worries that one possible effect of tariffs is a glut of domestically grown crops. Talley’s biggest concern is his farm’s workers, who could be affected by Trump’s stated intent of mass deportations.

Shawna Morris, executive vice president of trade policy at the National Milk Producers Federation, said she is concerned about California’s dairy exports to Mexico, including cheese. California’s dairy exports totaled $3.2 billion in 2022.

California’s biggest export, almonds, had $4.7 billion in foreign sales in 2022. Almond farmer Jenny Holtermann, in Kern County, said the tariffs won’t affect them instantly. Almond growers saw their prices drop from $2.50 a pound to $1.40 a pound after Trump’s tariffs in 2018, according to research from the University of California Giannini Foundation of Agricultural Economics. Holtermann said farmers’ costs have only gone up. She is counting on a couple of things: California almonds’ dominance (the state produces 80% of the world’s almonds, says the Almond Alliance) and another possible federal bailout. During the Trump 1.0 trade war, the federal government provided farmers with “market facilitation funds” of $23 billion.

Shannon Douglass, president of the California Farm Bureau, is concerned about getting global buyers to return once they switch to other sources. Almonds and pistachios saw a 20% drop in exports.

title: Here’s why China will bring Trump to his knees — and he knows it - (Published 18 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: “China restricting exports of rare earths is the thing that’s going to cause Trump to cave on China while declaring victory,” posted to X earlier this month, and reposted Thursday with a screenshot of ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump told reporters this week that “everything’s active” when asked if he was engaging with China over finding a solution to his trade war.

China on Thursday denied Trump’s assertion that the two sides were involved in active negotiations over tariffs.

A prominent Trump critic said there are two words to describe why Trump may soften his stance against China: Rare earths.

The Washington Post reported Thursday that Trump administration officials are “scrambling to stem economic damage from China’s restrictions on rare earth exports” as Trump’s trade war “risks cutting key industries and defense contractors off from supplies of metals crucial to production.”

Companies are scrambling for other suppliers and urging Trump’s administration to make peace with China since the country “has a lock on the supply of certain elements.”

Ashley Zumwalt-Forbes, who was a deputy director for batteries and critical materials at the Energy Department during the Biden administration, told the newspaper, “China knows this is a very strong bargaining chip, and it is why they are playing it. This is fast emerging as our Achilles’ heel. What makes these bans particularly dangerous is, oftentimes, one of these materials is a single point of failure for entire supply chains, and its production rests solely in China.”

The Korea Economic Daily reported that China “warned South Korean companies of retributions for exporting any product containing its critical metals to US military contractors.”

Ron Filipkowski, editor of MeidasTouch, posted to X earlier this month, and reposted Thursday with a screenshot of one of the author’s behind the Post’s story, “China restricting exports of rare earths is the thing that’s going to cause Trump to cave on China while declaring victory.”

Trump had put 145% tariffs on imports from China, while China hit back with 125% tariffs on U.S. products.

China remained the exception to Trump giving other countries a 90-day pause on the tariffs, as their leaders pledged to negotiate with the U.S.

Beijing raised its own tariffs and deployed other economic measures in response while vowing to “fight to the end.”

content: Caleb Ragland voted for Donald Trump three times and doesn’t regret it. But he is about to plant a field of crops that China loves to buy – and he is very worried.
resumen:
Caleb Ragland, a ninth-generation farmer and president of the American Soybean Association, is worried about the impact of the trade war sparked by Donald Trump’s 145 per cent tariffs on China.

During the last trade war with China, 71 per cent of the agricultural losses came from soy.

Ragland voted for Trump each time but is pleading with the president to strike a deal with Beijing to slash the current tariffs before the soybean harvest in October.

The US shipped 27 million tonnes of soybeans to China last year, worth about $US12.8 billion ($20 billion).

The wholesale price of soybeans has dropped 40 per cent over the last three years, from $US17 a bushel to $US10.

Ragland intends to plant his crop next month but knows of farmers in the area who will sit this year out.

Ragland worries he could be out of business by 2027.

Up to 38 centimetres of rain fell on parts of the Midwest farm belt in early April, the second bad flood this year after a February disaster that killed 22 people.

Trump signaled the 145 per cent tariffs on China cannot last.

Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins has said the administration would be prepared to again offer bailouts for farmers impacted by the trade war.

In his first term, Trump doled out about $US23 billion in compensation, after an estimated $US27 billion in agricultural losses.

One measure would spare automobiles and parts already subject to tariffs from facing additional duties from levies on steel and aluminum imports. Another option being studied would fully exempt auto parts that comply with the US-Mexico-Canada trade pact (USMCA). The Financial Times reported that the Trump administration is considering reducing tariffs on auto parts — and that it might also exempt auto parts bought from China from a 20 percent tariff applied to the nation over a dispute over fentanyl. The proposals and options remain under consideration, and Trump has not signed off. Trump’s tariff policies often change quickly, but the discussions offer a signal that the administration is considering ways to narrow the scope of levies affecting the auto industry. If adopted, the changes would be a significant reprieve for automakers, who have warned of devastating consequences from the tariffs, including higher vehicle prices, production cuts and potential job losses. Trump has separately applied tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico, although exempted USMCA-compliant goods. The tariffs on autos and auto parts were poised to heavily disrupt the integrated continental supply chain. The US plan, as initially announced, offered something of an olive branch by applying tariffs only on the non-US share of USMCA-traded vehicles, and delaying a potential tariff on parts traded under the pact. Trump on Wednesday indicated he was not considering changes to auto tariffs, while also suggesting he might even increase levies on the Canadian auto sector. title: BBC analysis: China’s five weapons against Trump’s tariffs and the trade war - (Published 16 hour(s), 1 minute(s) ago)
content: China claims it is ready to "fight to the end" – from a shift towards self-sufficiency to dominance in rare earth metals, Beijing demonstrates it has well-prepared for the clash with the US ...
resumen:
The trade war between the United States and China has entered a phase of direct confrontation. Washington has imposed tariffs of up to 245% on Chinese exports, while Beijing has retaliated with countermeasures and tariffs of 125% on American products. Chinese President Xi Jinping states he is ready to “fight to the end.” China is mobilizing a series of powerful “weapons” to strengthen its position and withstand the pressure.

Here are the five key advantages China holds in the ongoing trade war:

1.  **Economic Resilience and Domestic Consumption:** With a population exceeding one billion and a robust manufacturing base, China can endure greater pressures than other economies. The government is working to “unlock” the power of the domestic consumer through subsidy packages and incentives for retirees.
2.  **Investment in Technological Dominance:** China aims to lead in the new digital world with massive investments in artificial intelligence, green energy, microchips, and electric vehicles. Beijing announced a ten-year investment plan exceeding $1 trillion for innovation.
3.  **Decoupling from the U.S. and Pivoting to the Global South:** Since the first round of tariffs were imposed (under Trump in 2018), China has accelerated its drive for self-sufficiency. The Belt and Road initiative has strengthened relations with Southeast Asia, Africa, and Latin America. Today, China is the largest trading partner for 60 countries. Imports of soybeans from the U.S. have been halved.
4.  **Management of U.S. Bonds:** China holds about $700 billion in U.S. government bonds.
5.  **Dominance in Rare Earths and Strategic Metals:** China accounts for 61% of global rare earth production and 92% of its processing. These are irreplaceable elements in the production of electronics, AI chips, defense systems, and electric vehicles. Beijing has imposed restrictions on seven critical rare earth elements and recently banned exports of antimony.

content: Increasing competition from China and a contracting economy for two consecutive years have exacerbated export-driven Germany economy’s challenges. Trump’s aggressive tariff strategy has placed additio ...
resumen:
Germany’s economy, Europe’s largest, is expected to stagnate in 2025, weighed down by ongoing trade tensions initiated by US President Donald Trump and domestic political uncertainty.

Outgoing economy minister Robert Habeck announced on Thursday that the government has slashed its 2025 growth forecast to zero, down from an already modest 0.3 per cent anticipated in January. For 2026, growth expectations have also been slightly revised downward to 1 per cent, compared to the 1.1 per cent forecast earlier this year.

“There is above all one reason for this, namely Donald Trump’s trade policy and the effects of the trade policy on Germany,” Habeck told reporters in Berlin. He highlighted the additional complication posed by Germany’s lack of a parliamentary majority government since November, with a new administration still not officially established following February’s elections.

Germany, traditionally an export-driven economy renowned globally for its luxury cars and industrial machinery, has struggled to achieve significant growth in recent years. Increasing competition from China and a contracting economy for two consecutive years have exacerbated these challenges.

Trump’s aggressive tariff strategy has placed additional strain on German exporters. Last year, the United States replaced China as Germany’s largest trading partner for the first time since 2015, as exports to China declined sharply amid escalating tensions.

Germany’s parliament is set to convene on May 6 to vote on Friedrich Merz as the nation’s new leader, pending approval of the coalition agreement reached earlier this month.

title: Trump’s Global Tariffs Are Meant For China - (Published 11 hour(s), 56 minute(s) ago)
content: Donald Trump’s “Liberation Day” on April 2, 2025, marked the formal launch of sweeping global tariffs, capping months of escalatory announcements since returning to office. Amplifying the economic ...
resumen: On April 2, 2025, Donald Trump launched global tariffs, amplifying the economic nationalism of his first term. This action is the culmination of Trump's advocacy for raising tariffs and reviving American industry, building on previous efforts to recalibrate trade. Influenced by Project 2025's chapter on fair trade by Peter Navarro, it calls for rapid trade action to reduce deficits, lower debt, and reshore manufacturing. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has framed tariffs as part of a larger economic realignment to restore U.S. industrial and economic dominance. Trump aims to break the dominance of China’s export-led economic model, with some consequences for the U.S. economy. While his strategy builds on former efforts to reshape trade, it has only modest domestic support. The gamble carries risks of global economic destabilization, blowback from allies, and handing China more power. From 1798 to 1913, tariffs covered 50 to 90 percent of income. After World War II, the U.S. aimed to rebuild allied economies by opening its markets. Trade deficits emerged by the 1970s, but abandoning the gold standard in 1971 let the U.S. print dollars more easily. The Cold War’s end in the early 1990s left the U.S. confident it could continue steering global trade. It pushed for global tariff cuts and free trade deals like NAFTA, while U.S. corporations helped build up foreign manufacturing, particularly in China. American consumers absorbed global overproduction, and corporate profits soared, but many American workers were increasingly left behind. These policies added to the anti-globalization movements of the late 1990s, prompting a rethink of trade policy. Domestic industries like steel had collapsed under cheap imports. The 2008 financial crisis brought bipartisan calls for economic restructuring. Trump’s first-term trade agenda broke from previous caution. Favoring unilateral action, he withdrew from the TPP in 2017, clashed with the WTO, and renegotiated NAFTA. He then imposed tariffs on key trade partners, especially China. By then, the cost of offshoring had become clear. With U.S. corporate assistance, China had gained capital and technology expertise to become the “world’s factory.” Low-tariff access to the U.S. market gave Beijing a $300 billion surplus over America in 2024, and it emerged as the world’s top exporter and creditor. President Biden raised tariffs on China. Like China, the EU and Japan had established large trade surpluses with the U.S., an issue he sought to address. Trump’s second-term focus has again hit allies, yet the attention remains squarely on China, with individual tariffs on other countries being paused on April 9, while tariffs on Beijing have increased. Aside from direct exports, Washington also seeks to target China’s role in global trade. Biden’s push to “nearshore” manufacturing to countries like Mexico exposed the limits of decoupling, as Chinese companies quickly established themselves in new Mexican industrial parks. Many imports shipped to the U.S. from other countries also contain Chinese components, meaning Trump’s 10 percent “baseline” tariff hike on all imports is meant to counteract other countries serving as conduits for Chinese goods. In Project 2025, Peter Navarro emphasized the role of non-tariff barriers. In early February 2025, Trump cited fentanyl smuggling as justification for raising tariffs on China, Mexico, and Canada. A tariff war will raise prices for consumers and businesses. Uncertainty over Trump’s policies saw a fake tweet about tariffs on April 7 trigger multi-trillion-dollar swings. Prolonged stock volatility or declines would reduce pensions, household wealth, and corporate valuations. China has retaliated by raising its own tariffs and halting exports of rare earths and critical minerals. Its state-backed firms can flood global markets with cheap goods and advanced tech. With a growing presence in international institutions and trade blocs, Beijing could increasingly shape global economic norms. Trump also wants to devalue the dollar to make U.S. exports more competitive, but insists on keeping the dollar as the world’s reserve currency. His approach is undermining global confidence in the dollar. Trump’s pressure on a resistant Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further reflects limited borrowing options and coordination in U.S. financial policy. Democrats have largely avoided serious condemnation of Trump’s policies. Trump’s policies have some support from the U.S. business class. Chinese companies like Temu, Shein, and BYD increasingly threaten giants like Amazon and Tesla. Any success in bringing manufacturing back will mostly come through automation. Trump has framed tariffs as leverage over trading partners and a source of revenue. His 2024 campaign called for cutting the corporate tax rate to 15 percent, down from 21 percent. The promised economic boom was not evident before COVID-19 hit. The U.S. needs to expand production for both domestic use and exports, but current capacity falls far short. Compared to Trump’s approach, China and the EU have positioned themselves as stable anchors of the global economy. U.S. calls to coordinate with major economic allies like the EU and Japan to limit dealings with China risk falling on deaf ears. The U.S. accounted for roughly 13 percent of global import consumption in 2023. China, facing a property crisis, high youth unemployment, and mounting local government debt, has pledged to “vigorously boost domestic consumption.” The EU has signaled it will not tolerate a flood of Chinese goods. The EU and Canada have raised tariffs on the U.S. The Trump administration has tested EU unity. Forcing a global trade war is likely to further weaken China’s export-led model. As the U.S. signals a reduced role in safeguarding global maritime trade, geopolitical tensions could disrupt other key routes. Trump frequently changed tactics in his first term.

title: Donald Trump Is Tanking One of America’s Greatest Exports in the Middle of a Trade War - (Published 14 hour(s), 5 minute(s) ago)
content: Sign up for the Slatest to get the most insightful analysis, criticism, and advice out there, delivered to your inbox daily.
resumen: The United States exports more than $44 billion per year in education and accompanying services. This is more revenue than any other category of services: more than travel services, more than business services, more than financial services, and many multiples of computer, health, and legal services. Education raises more revenue from foreign countries than all but a handful of categories of American goods and commodities, only slightly less than pharmaceuticals and far more than iron and steel, plastics, furniture, dairy products, and even soybeans. Well over 1 million foreigners purchase U.S.-produced education each year, according to the Institute of International Education. They pay American businesses for food, shelter, transportation, and entertainment while they are here, supporting 400,000 American jobs. The Trump administration is intentionally trying to destroy the product, slashing billions of dollars of grant funding to leading research universities and specifically targeting those, most recently Harvard, that refuse to change their internal governance. The administration seems committed to making foreign students believe they cannot safely purchase education from the United States by canceling student visas arbitrarily and detaining and deporting noncitizens who have not committed any crimes for exercising the freedom of speech. Secretary of State Marco Rubio ordered that student visa applicants have their social media accounts reviewed and, in some cases, undergo “enhanced screening.” Coupled with wholesale firing of tens of thousands of government employees, including deep cuts in State Department staff announced this week, these directives call into question whether foreign students who still want to come to the United States to study this fall will be approved in time to do so. Secretary Rubio calls them “guests” and says a student visa is a “privilege.”

title: Trump’s Tariffs Expected to Grind Germany’s Growth to a Halt - (Published 18 hour(s), 42 minute(s) ago)
content: The German government scaled back its prediction for 2025 to zero economic growth, citing the turbulence caused by U.S. tariffs, as well as stubborn bureaucracy and high energy prices.
resumen: Germany’s economy will not grow for the third year in a row, the government said on Thursday, scaling back a previous prediction. In January, the German government had predicted 0.3 percent economic growth. Mr. Trump’s tariffs of 25 percent on imported automobiles, steel and aluminum threaten to hit Germany’s export-oriented economy hard. The German economy is already suffering from weak foreign demand and reduced competitiveness. Germany is the only member of the Group of 7 nations whose economy has failed to grow in the past two years. A new German government will take power after the expected next chancellor, Friedrich Merz, is sworn in on May 6. He has promised to spur growth, aided by looser borrowing limits that will allow the government to spend hundreds of billions of euros on defense and infrastructure. Economists warn that unless the country tackles some of the underlying structural problems — including a burdensome bureaucracy, one of Europe’s highest corporate tax rates and soaring energy prices — even the extended borrowing will not bring relief. Germany is also facing a demographic problem, leading to a shrinking work force and a drop in productivity. The country is grappling with a surging anti-immigrant sentiment. Many companies have scaled back their growth outlook as they digest the 10 percent blanket tariff on goods exported to the United States. The government now predicts growth of 1 percent for 2026. Helena Melnikov, managing director of the German Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said, “If the new German government does not take decisive and swift countermeasures, we could even face a significant third consecutive year of recession.” The International Monetary Fund also predicted that Germany’s economy would not grow this year, cutting its forecast to 0 percent from 0.2 percent in January. Growth across the wider eurozone was also scaled down to 0.8 percent from 1 percent, the I.M.F. said.

title: Trump trade war spreads more gloom across various businesses - (Published 14 hour(s), 16 minute(s) ago)
content: Businesses across multiple industries are increasing prices, cutting financial guidance and warning of growing uncertainty as US President Donald ...
resumen:
Businesses across multiple industries are increasing prices, cutting financial guidance and warning of growing uncertainty as US President Donald Trump’s trade war pushes up costs, up-ends supply chains and stirs concerns about the global economy.

Earning releases on Thursday showed that corporations around the world ran into a wall of uncertainty in the first quarter, as executives found themselves navigating the Trump administration’s constantly shifting stance on trade.

Comments from the biggest packaged food, drinks and consumer goods companies also underscored worries among businesses and investors that Trump’s tariffs and his attacks on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will hurt confidence on Main Street.

Procter & Gamble CFO Andre Schulten said on a media call after the Pampers maker announced plans to hike prices to cover the impact of extra costs from the sweeping tariff war.

Nestle CEO Laurent Freixe and Dove soap maker Unilever also flagged weakening US consumer confidence.

Stocks drifted on Thursday and a rebound in the dollar fizzled out as investors tried to pick through the Trump administration’s fast-changing announcements on tariffs and the leadership of the Fed, the US central bank.

While most of the tariffs have been paused for 90 days until July 8, a 10% universal rate and duties on aluminium, steel and car imports remain in place, as do eye-popping levies on goods imported from China, to which Beijing has responded in kind.

The Trump administration will look at lowering tariffs on imported Chinese goods pending talks between the two countries, a source told Reuters on Wednesday.

With the first-quarter earnings season entering its second busy week, companies were counting the costs of the chaos and setting out how they plan to stem the fallout.

P&G, soda and snacks giant PepsiCo and medical equipment maker Thermo Fisher Scientific, became the latest companies to cut annual profit forecasts, citing trade turmoil.

American Airlines withdrew its 2025 financial guidance, mirroring its peers.

Thermo Fisher also warned of the impact of the Trump administration’s proposed cuts to academic research funding.

P&G’s Schulten said pricing and cost cuts were its main means of weathering the storm as changing its raw materials sourcing from China would be difficult in the short term due to lack of alternatives.

Almost 30 companies around the globe have either withdrawn or cut their forecasts in the past two weeks, a Reuters analysis shows.

Earlier on Thursday, Hyundai Motor said it had launched a task force to handle its response to the tariffs and moved production of some Tucson crossover vehicles from Mexico to the United States.

The automaker said: “We expect a challenging business outlook to continue due to intensifying trade wars and other various unpredictable macroeconomic factors.”

The company is also considering whether to move production of some U.S.-bound cars from South Korea to other locations, it said as it reaffirmed its annual earnings targets.

Hyundai and affiliate Kia, which together are the world’s third-biggest automaking group by sales, generate about one-third of their global sales from the US market and imports account for roughly two-thirds of their US car sales.

Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com said nearly 3,000 firms have already made enquiries about its 200 billion yuan ($27.35 billion) fund, announced on April 11, to help exporters sell their products domestically over the next year.

Adding to worries about economic weakness, the German government cut its 2025 growth forecast on Thursday and now sees stagnation instead of a 0.3% expansion as uncertainty from global trade disputes hobbles growth and dampens investment.

Essity’s CEO Magnus Groth told Reuters the Swedish tissue maker had seen a drop in demand for hygiene products from hotels and restaurants in North America because people are eating out less and may not be travelling.

Chipotle Mexican Grill late on Wednesday warned that Americans are spending less on dining out due to elevated economic uncertainty, prompting the food chain to cut its sales outlook.

Telecoms equipment maker Nokia flagged a short-term disruption from US tariffs, while Dassault Systemes , which sells software to automakers, plane manufacturers and defence companies, cut its forecast profit margin due to tariff-related market volatility, knocking its shares.

Nestle and Unilever delivered better-than-expected quarterly sales, but they and their big-brand rivals are easing US price increases to avoid losing American shoppers to retailers’ less expensive private-label brands.

Other companies, including Ray-Ban maker EssilorLuxottica, LG Electronics and Interparfums have said they are hiking US prices or may do so.

title: Solo el 18% de las exportaciones de Colombia a Estados Unidos sufre un impacto significativo por los aranceles de Trump - (Published Apr 23, 2025)
content: Un estudio de la Cámara de Comercio Colombo - Americana calcula que el 40% de la canasta exportadora tendría oportunidades altas o medias de aprovechar el cambio ...
resumen: Un estudio de la Cámara de Comercio Colombo - Americana (AmCham Colombia) indica que solo el 17,3% de las exportaciones de Colombia a Estados Unidos sufre un impacto significativo por los aranceles del 10% impuestos por el Gobierno estadounidense. El estudio calcula que el 40% de la canasta exportadora tendría oportunidades altas o medias de aprovechar el cambio. Las exportaciones hacia Estados Unidos podrían caer un 8% -lo que representa unos 1.100 millones de dólares en negocios- y se podrían perder un total de 15.000 empleos. El 87,2% de los productos de exportación sentirán un impacto limitado y tendrán oportunidades de aprovechar el ajuste. El 40% tendrá oportunidades que califica como altas o media-altas para consolidar y expandir la presencia de Colombia en ese mercado. El 6% de los productos tienen una alta oportunidad de consolidación en Estados Unidos con la nueva situación arancelaria, especialmente el material eléctrico, los textiles y las confecciones, y los azúcares y productos de confitería. El 34% de los productos que se encuentran en la franja de la oportunidad alta-media se compone de las flores y las plantas, el café, el aluminio y sus subproductos, el plástico o las preparaciones de hortalizas y frutas procesadas. Un 2,6% de los productos tendrían un impacto negativo por cuenta de las desventajas frente a México, incluyendo el aguacate, el limón tahití y el cacao. Un análisis de AmCham, elaborado por el centro de estudios Asociación Nacional de Instituciones Financieras (ANIF), indica que, de mantenerse el arancel del 10% por dos años, la reducción de las exportaciones resultante afectaría principalmente al sector minero-energético, que en 2024 representó el 59,9% del total de mercancía exportada hacia Estados Unidos. ANIF proyecta que los aranceles reducirían en 0,1% el producto interno bruto (PIB) en 2025, y calcula que, si Colombia impone unos aranceles iguales a los productos de Estados Unidos, la inflación pasaría del 4,2% proyectado a un 4,4% definitivo. El 3 de abril, el Gobierno estadounidense anunció que el 51% de los productos colombianos quedarían exentos de aranceles, incluyendo los combustibles (que representan el 40% del total de las exportaciones de Colombia a Estados Unidos) y el oro y los metales preciosos (un 13% del total de exportaciones). Otros productos clave como las flores y el café sí tendrán el 10% de los aranceles, en pausa por 90 días desde el 9 de abril. La canciller Laura Sarabia ha dicho que la postura es seguir buscando entendimientos con Estados Unidos para no quebrar la relación, pero no ha ocultado la intención del Ejecutivo de diversificar sus socios en el mundo para impulsar el comercio con países de Europa, Asia y América Latina. La presidenta de AmCham Colombia, María Claudia Lacouture, hizo un llamado para que se cree un plan que disminuya el impacto de los aranceles.

El portavoz de Exteriores de China, Guo Jiakun, respondió que Washington «no tiene apoyos» en su guerra arancelaria, y que «más y más países se resistirán».

title: Uruguay ante un nuevo mundo comercial - (Published Apr 23, 2025)
content: El 2 de abril, el presidente de Estados Unidos dio un batacazo al orden comercial del mundo al anunciar un conjunto de tarifas a aplicar a casi todas las importaciones del país que dirige, en lo que l ...
resumen:
El 2 de abril, el presidente de Estados Unidos anunció tarifas a aplicar a casi todas las importaciones del país, en lo que llamó el “día de la liberación” de Estados Unidos.

Estados Unidos está tomando medidas fuertes en la dirección de cerrar su economía a las importaciones del resto del mundo.

Otras economías importantes están dispuestas a responder, subiendo también las tarifas que aplican ellos a sus importaciones desde Estados Unidos. La Unión Europea y China ya han hecho anuncios en este sentido.

Fuera de estas barreras comerciales que se elevan alrededor de Estados Unidos, el resto del mundo parece seguir dispuesto a reforzar el comercio entre el resto de los socios.

El efecto directo de las tarifas de Donald Trump sobre la economía uruguaya no aparecería como algo mayor.

Estados Unidos no se ubica entre los socios comerciales más importantes de Uruguay, ya que representa solamente entre el 4% y el 5% de nuestras exportaciones.

Para algunos sectores particulares el efecto puede ser notable. De las exportaciones de Uruguay a Estados Unidos, algo más de la mitad se concentran en el rubro ganadero.

Uruguay no ha establecido suba de tarifas alguna sobre los productos provenientes de Estados Unidos, por lo que no deberían esperarse efectos directos importantes sobre los precios de los productos que importamos desde ese país (sobre todo, productos farmacéuticos y maquinaria).

Los efectos indirectos pueden ser más interesantes.

Habrá una gran cantidad de producción china que planeaba venderse en Estados Unidos, pero que ahora deberá encontrar nuevos mercados, deprimiendo su precio. Esto afectará sobre todo a los artículos electrónicos (computadoras, celulares, tablets) y textiles (ropa), que normalmente ocupan más de la mitad de las exportaciones de China hacia Estados Unidos.

Estos son también el tipo de productos que Uruguay le compra a China, por lo que podría esperarse una reducción de los precios en el mercado local de estos artículos de consumo.

China ha penalizado las importaciones desde Estados Unidos, especialmente en la órbita de los productos agropecuarios.

Habría que esperar, entonces, una profundización de nuestras exportaciones agropecuarias hacia China y un incremento de los precios, dada la mayor demanda.

Los productos que Estados Unidos estipulaba colocar en China tienen que terminar en algún lado, y pueden terminar compitiendo con nuestras exportaciones por algunos mercados.

Podría observarse una reducción de precios en Uruguay de productos estadounidenses. En los últimos años, nuestras importaciones desde Estados Unidos se concentran en productos químicos y farmacéuticos, automóviles y autopartes, y maquinaria.

Podría haber presión para la reducción de los precios de estos productos en la plaza doméstica.

Productos de este tipo provenientes de Europa podrían llegar más baratos al mercado local al no poder entrar fácilmente a Estados Unidos.

La aplicación de tarifas con este alcance y en esta magnitud por parte de una economía que tiene un rol central en la economía global no representa una buena noticia para el mundo.

Para el caso concreto de Uruguay, los efectos negativos pueden verse atenuados.

Uruguay seguramente exportará menos a Estados Unidos, pero es esperable que pueda redirigir buena parte de esas exportaciones a otros mercados que ahora aparecerán más abiertos, principalmente China y tal vez también la Unión Europea.

Cabe esperar una presión a la baja sobre los precios de varios productos que normalmente terminaban en Estados Unidos o Europa; dados los nuevos muros comerciales, estos tendrán que encontrar nuevos mercados a precios menores, lo que podría beneficiar al consumidor uruguayo.

Debería esperarse un crecimiento global menor que el que habría sido en ausencia de estas tarifas, como ya comenzaron a anticipar las últimas proyecciones de los organismos internacionales.

title: FMI vislumbra “reseteo del sistema internacional de comercio” - (Published Apr 23, 2025)
content: Será prudente darle seguimiento a futuras actualizaciones probablemente en julio y luego en octubre 2025 para que el FMI pueda afinar la puntería, incluyendo también el comportamiento real de las econ ...
resumen:
El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), en su edición de abril 2025 de “Perspectivas de la Economía Mundial”, publicó revisiones a la baja en sus proyecciones de crecimiento de la economía global para 2025 y 2026. La directora gerente del FMI, Kristalina Georgieva, denomina como “reseteo del sistema internacional de comercio” el rediseño del mapa comercial global por parte del gobierno de Estados Unidos. El FMI advierte que se trata de un “pronóstico de referencias” en base a las informaciones disponibles al 4 de abril 2025.

El FMI proyecta un descenso del crecimiento global a 2.8% en 2025, por debajo del 3.3% de 2024 y de la proyección de 3.2% que había elaborado en octubre 2024. El FMI estima a medio punto porcentual el impacto de las medidas anunciadas por la Casa Blanca.

Argentina tiene un crecimiento del PIB estimado en 5.5% vs. 5% en la proyección de octubre 2024. República Dominicana recibió a 129,203 turistas argentinos en el primer trimestre, un crecimiento de un 94.7% por encima de los 66,368 arribados en enero-junio de 2024.

En Estados Unidos, el FMI proyecta una revisión a la baja a 1.8% en 2025, después de crecer 2.8% en 2024. México tiene una proyección de -0.3% en 2025, después de crecer 1.5% en 2024.

Latinoamérica y el Caribe (LAC) creció 2.4% en 2024, se proyectaba para este año un 2.5%, pero se revisó a la baja, a 2% para 2025.

En Centroamérica, Guatemala tiene una revisión al alza de 3.7% en 2024 a 4.1% en 2025. El Salvador de 2.6% (2024) a 2.5% (2025); Honduras 3.6% (2024) a un 3.3% (2025) y Nicaragua de 3.6% (2024) a 3.2% (2025). Costa Rica se proyecta para 2025 con 3.4%, y República Dominicana pasaría de un 5% (2024) a 4% (2025). En marzo 2025 se había reducido de 4.75% (presupuesto 2025) a 4.5% la proyección para este año.

title: Citi ‘enciende la alerta’: México cayó en recesión técnica al cierre de marzo. - (Published Apr 23, 2025)
content: Analistas de Citi alertaron que prevén un crecimiento anual del PIB de México en 0.2% al cierre de 2025. Ciudad ...
resumen:
Citi alertó que México cayó en recesión técnica al cierre de marzo de 2025.
Se prevé un crecimiento anual del PIB de México en 0.2% al cierre de 2025.
La economía mexicana acumuló dos trimestres consecutivos con retrocesos al concluir el tercer mes del año.
El PIB descendió 0.4 por ciento de enero a marzo.
En el cuarto trimestre del año pasado disminuyó 0.6 por ciento.
Citi prevé que la economía del país crecerá 0.2 por ciento el segundo trimestre y 0.4 por ciento durante el tercero y cuarto trimestre de 2025.
El PIB promediaría un crecimiento de 0.2 por ciento en todo el año de 2025.
La previsión de crecimiento del 0,2 por ciento coincide con el proyectado por los analistas encuestados por Citi.
Se espera 1.1 por ciento de crecimiento en Estados Unidos y el consenso lo prevé en 1.7 por ciento.
La incertidumbre está afectando la inversión.
México tendrá el peor crecimiento económico en América Latina.
El PIB del país registrará el peor desempeño entre 12 economías del subcontinente que monitorea la institución.
Argentina liderará el crecimiento en América Latina con un avance del 5 por ciento.
El promedio de avance del PIB de la región será de 2,2 por ciento.
Se refrendan los pronósticos de contracción de la inversión durante 2025 de 0.8 por ciento.
Los principales vientos en contra para la economía mexicana este año serán los aranceles de Trump, estiman un arancel efectivo de 7.3 por ciento.
La revisión del T-MEC programada para mediados de 2026 es otra fuente de incertidumbre.
Las reformas al poder judicial son otro factor que abona a la incertidumbre en México.
Se debe disminuir el déficit ampliado de 5.7 por ciento a un rango de 3.9 a 4 por ciento.
Se estima un déficit fiscal de 5,3 por ciento del PIB.
Los pronósticos de inflación general es de 3.9 para 2025 y 3.7 para 2026.
La inflación subyacente es de 3.7 por ciento para 2025 y 3.6 por ciento el siguiente año.
Una actividad económica débil y una inflación bien comportada sigue dando espacio para que el Banco de México continúe disminuyendo su tasa de interés.
Se estima para el cierre de 2026 una tasa de 6.25.
Se calcularon cinco recortes de tasa de la FED para 2026 dejando la tasa en 3.25 por ciento.
En 2024 el remanente bruto de operación de Banxico fue de 3 puntos del PIB, pero de ello, deberá destinar 2 puntos del PIB a resarcir pérdidas de ejercicios anteriores.
El remanente que transferiría Banxico al gobierno sería de 0.5 por ciento del PIB, equivalente a 175 mil millones de pesos.
El banco central, podría reservarse 0.5 por ciento del PIB.
Con la transferencia, el déficit fiscal del gobierno podría ser de 4,5 por ciento del PIB.

title: DWS refuerza su apuesta por Europa ante la pérdida de atractivo del mercado estadounidense - (Published Apr 23, 2025)
content: La creciente incertidumbre política en EE.UU. impulsa un cambio estructural en los flujos globales hacia Europa, según el equipo de renta variable europea de DWS. Alemania, pese a sus desafíos energét ...
resumen:
El equipo de renta variable europea de DWS, liderado por Marcus Poppe y Philipp Schweneke, ha iniciado un giro estratégico en sus carteras. La decisión responde a un entorno cada vez más volátil en Estados Unidos, especialmente tras el llamado Liberation Day, marcado por un giro proteccionista que amenaza el estatus de refugio del país.

Poppe señala que el riesgo de que EE.UU. pierda su estatus de activo refugio es real. El entorno actual, caracterizado por la inestabilidad regulatoria, amenazas arancelarias y pérdida de poder blando, está llevando a muchos inversores internacionales a diversificar fuera de EE.UU. Han aumentado exposición a Europa y reducido significativamente la exposición al dólar y a activos ligados al PIB estadounidense.

Aunque Alemania ha flirteado con la recesión, los gestores de DWS destacan su capacidad estructural para resistir y adaptarse. Las grandes compañías alemanas, altamente internacionalizadas, han amortiguado el impacto local: el DAX genera cerca del 80% de sus ingresos fuera de Alemania.

Segmentos como automatización, tecnología médica o software industrial ofrecen oportunidades crecientes. La industria alemana necesita reformas para estimular la inversión, según Schweneke.

El nuevo gobierno alemán ha presentado un programa orientado a reducir la burocracia, limitar el exceso regulatorio y rebajar gradualmente el impuesto de sociedades.

Alemania, con una deuda pública inferior al 60% del PIB, tiene capacidad para endeudarse y financiar infraestructuras críticas sin comprometer su solvencia. La clave será que ese gasto se dirija a activos productivos: redes eléctricas, transporte, digitalización y defensa.

El avance de las renovables y la eliminación de barreras a nuevos proyectos están empezando a aliviar el entorno de costes. En 2024, se aprobaron 20 GW de capacidad eólica terrestre. Alemania no será una base energética barata, pero tiene margen para adaptarse y seguir siendo competitiva, sostiene Poppe.

El regreso de Donald Trump como figura central en la política estadounidense ha actuado como catalizador. Lo más preocupante no son solo las amenazas arancelarias, sino la ruptura de la previsibilidad institucional que caracterizaba a EE.UU.

Las empresas ya no pueden tomar decisiones de inversión con seguridad. Esa volatilidad está afectando no solo a la política comercial, sino también al atractivo del dólar como reserva de valor. Por primera vez, muchos inversores están cuestionando la centralidad del mercado estadounidense en sus carteras, agrega Schweneke.

Europa puede posicionarse como un ancla de estabilidad relativa, con instituciones más predecibles y un enfoque más pragmático en política económica y comercial. La reacción europea a esta coyuntura —mayor integración, impulso al gasto en defensa e infraestructuras y posible avance en acuerdos como Mercosur— refuerza esta percepción.

DWS ha optado por ajustar sus carteras con un enfoque equilibrado, sin caer en posicionamientos extremos. Han incrementado el peso en sectores europeos defensivos, pero también mantienen exposición selectiva a industriales cíclicos con valoraciones atractivas.

Entre los sectores destacados figuran infraestructuras, aseguradoras, bancos, tecnología industrial y defensa. En cambio, compañías con alta sensibilidad al ciclo estadounidense han sido parcialmente reducidas. El objetivo es minimizar la exposición al riesgo específico de EE.UU., pero sin renunciar a buenas ideas de inversión.

Han incrementado los niveles de liquidez en algunas estrategias y reducido el apalancamiento en fondos sobreexpuestos. Actuar con humildad es esencial en este entorno.

Respecto a los flujos a sus fondos de inversión, de momento no se ha observado una fuerte entrada, pero son conscientes de que los inversores utilizan ETF para hacer movimientos tácticos. Muchos inversores en este roadshow por Europa, Latinoamérica y Asia se muestran con deseo de "esta vez si" aumentar peso a Europa en sus carteras.

DWS no anticipa un gran año de crecimiento en beneficios, pero considera que los riesgos ya están parcialmente descontados en precios. A medio plazo, observan un mayor interés estructural en Europa por parte de inversores institucionales globales. La recuperación de flujos hacia activos europeos —visible ya en el segmento de ETF— podría consolidarse si persiste la incertidumbre en EE.UU.

La rotación que están viendo no es solo táctica. Existe una creciente voluntad de reducir la sobreexposición global a EE.UU. y Europa es uno de los destinos más naturales.

title: Paraguay se apoya en sus vecinos del Mercosur ante riesgos por guerra comercial - (Published 15 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: (Bloomberg) -- La pertenencia a uno de los bloques comerciales más proteccionistas del mundo ayudará a Paraguay a amortiguar las peores disrupciones a corto plazo provocadas por los aranceles de EE.UU ...
resumen: La pertenencia a uno de los bloques comerciales más proteccionistas del mundo ayudará a Paraguay a amortiguar las peores disrupciones a corto plazo provocadas por los aranceles de EE.UU., afirmó el ministro de Economía y Finanzas del país en una entrevista. En medio de crecientes tensiones comerciales globales, Paraguay busca profundizar sus lazos políticos y económicos con vecinos como Brasil y Argentina dentro del Mercado Común del Sur, o Mercosur, el cual también incluye a Uruguay. El ministro de Economía y Finanzas, Carlos Fernández Valdovinos, dijo al margen de las reuniones de primavera del FMI en Washington: “Estamos pidiendo más integración regional en Sudamérica si estamos teniendo problemas en el norte. Si ya no podemos comerciar de sur a norte, empecemos a comerciar de sur a sur.” Un acuerdo comercial con la Unión Europea se concretó en diciembre tras más de dos décadas de negociaciones. Tras los anuncios de aranceles de Donald Trump, los países del Mercosur decidieron relajar algunos aranceles externos comunes para permitir mayor flexibilidad en futuras negociaciones o represalias. El presidente de Brasil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, también renovó los llamados a fortalecer los lazos económicos dentro de América Latina como contrapeso a la guerra comercial entre EE.UU. y China. Con una economía de US$45.000 millones, Paraguay depende en gran medida del comercio con Argentina y Brasil, que en conjunto representaron el 63% de sus exportaciones el año pasado. Fernández dijo: “Estamos preparados para cualquier impacto externo. Vivimos en un vecindario difícil, rodeados por Argentina y Brasil. Dadas nuestras relaciones comerciales y la integración económica con ellos, la volatilidad en esos dos países tiene mucho más peso que la que pueda venir desde EE.UU.” El Mercosur espera firmar un acuerdo de libre comercio con los Emiratos Árabes Unidos antes de finales de 2025. Debido a un arancel del 10% que resta competitividad a la carne paraguaya en EE.UU., el país también busca vender más a mercados como Corea, Japón y Taiwán. Cerca del 20% de su población de 6,1 millones vive en la pobreza. Su banco central revisó al alza su pronóstico de crecimiento para este año, del 3,8% al 4%. Paraguay obtuvo el año pasado su primera calificación de grado de inversión cuando Moody’s elevó su nota a Baa3 desde Ba1, con perspectiva positiva. S&P y Fitch mantienen al país un escalón por debajo, en BB+. El gobierno busca reducir el déficit fiscal al 1,9% del PIB este año, y al 1,5% para fines de 2026. En febrero, Paraguay colocó US$1.200 millones en bonos globales, mitad en moneda local y mitad en dólares. Fue el segundo año consecutivo que emitió bonos en guaraníes en los mercados internacionales. El país buscará financiamiento en el mercado local en lugar de acudir nuevamente al internacional, procurando no competir con el sector privado, indicó Fernández. Los bonos en dólares de Paraguay han rendido un 0,5% este año. Paraguay es uno de los pocos países que mantienen relaciones diplomáticas con Taiwán. China ha ganado terreno en América Latina. El país registró un déficit comercial de más de US$5.100 millones con la potencia asiática el año pasado. Fernández dijo: “No tenemos problema en firmar un acuerdo de libre comercio con China. Estamos abiertos a eso. El único asunto es que queremos elegir con quién vamos a tomar una cerveza. Queremos elegir a nuestros amigos. Somos amigos de Taiwán.”

title: Trump Takes On Improbable Task in Seeking Trade Deals Across the Globe - (Published 10 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: The president’s threats of tariffs have brought countries like Japan, South Korea and India rushing to negotiate, but they have sown chaos with bigger trading partners like China.
resumen:
For a president who advertises himself as a paramount deal maker, the next 11 weeks will be a pivotal test, as his advisers race to accomplish what no other administration has done before and reach dozens of individual trade deals with other governments.

President Trump has promised big gains for American trade, and officials from Japan, South Korea, India and elsewhere have been pushing for agreements as they look to forestall punishing tariffs.

Trade experts say the administration has set up a seemingly impossible task, given that traditional trade deals typically take months or years to negotiate.

Mr. Trump has tried to use tariffs as leverage to notch quick agreements, and his trade adviser, Peter Navarro, has promised “90 deals in 90 days.”

The levies are creating chaos and financial pain for many businesses, and they have not brought some of America’s largest trading partners, including China, to the table.

Some U.S. trade with China has ground to a halt after the countries imposed triple-digit tariffs on each others’ products, and a wave of bankruptcies, especially among small U.S. businesses that rely on Chinese imports, appears to be looming if the trade barriers are maintained.

Some Trump officials recognize that the situation with China is not sustainable and have been strategizing how to reduce the tariffs between the countries, two people familiar with the discussions said.

Administration officials were concerned about the hit to the stock market, which has experienced intense volatility and some of its worst trading days in years. The S&P 500 is down 10 percent since Mr. Trump’s Jan. 20 inauguration.

Speaking from the Oval Office on Wednesday, Mr. Trump said he wanted to make a deal with China. But he said what happens with his tariffs on China “depends on them.”

He denied any concerns about what the tariffs are doing to small businesses, but said that the high tariff “basically means China isn’t doing any business with us.”

He also claimed the United States had spoken with 90 countries, all of which wanted to do deals.

On Tuesday, Mr. Trump signaled that the 145 percent tariff he put on Chinese imports could drop.

So far, officials from the United States and China do not appear to have engaged in substantive talks over the trade spat.

Trump officials believe the Chinese economy is vulnerable, given its dependence on exports to the United States.

“President Trump has been clear: China needs to make a deal with the United States of America,” said Kush Desai, a White House spokesman.

Scott Bessent, the Treasury secretary, on Wednesday dismissed speculation that the president was considering unilaterally lowering the tariffs that he had imposed on China ahead of any negotiations with Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader.

He emphasized that any moves to de-escalate trade tensions would need to be mutual.

On Wednesday, Guo Jiakun, the spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry, reiterated that China would not be bullied by U.S. tariff threats.

Mr. Trump’s tariff threats have created urgency for other governments, motivating them to begin talks with the United States about removing tariffs and other trade barriers.

On April 9, just hours after the president imposed stiff tariffs on nearly 60 countries, he paused them for 90 days, saying he would give governments a chance to negotiate trade deals instead.

This week, Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, said that the Trump administration had received 18 proposals on paper and that the trade team was “meeting with 34 countries this week alone.”

Negotiating so many deals at the same time poses significant challenges.

Many of Mr. Trump’s departments are still understaffed, with midlevel officials not yet confirmed.

Torsten Slok, the chief economist at Apollo Global Management, an investment firm, wrote online that on average, trade deals signed by the United States had taken 18 months to negotiate and 45 months to implement.

Foreign governments say they do not know exactly what the Trump administration wants.

Greta Peisch, a former trade official who is now a partner at the law firm Wiley Rein, said the tight timeline raised questions about whether any deals concluded in the next few months would be “more tentative or aspirational” rather than actual trade agreements.

South Korean finance and trade ministers were set to meet with Mr. Bessent and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative, on Thursday.

Officials from Thailand, Japan, India and other countries were also scheduled to hold talks in Washington this week.

In a visit to New Delhi on Tuesday, Vice President JD Vance announced the outlines for a potential trade agreement with India, which would ramp up trade between the countries, reduce Indian barriers to U.S. exports and fold in discussions of defense, energy and strategic technologies.

While the Trump administration has said some deals could be concluded quickly, initial meetings have suggested that talks could be more complicated, particularly with major trading partners like Japan.

The two nations have trade disputes extending back decades over industries like steel and auto parts.

Some agreements under discussion — for example, a project that could see Japan, South Korea and Taiwan invest in a pipeline to export liquefied natural gas from Alaska — could take at least five years to come to fruition.

South Korean officials also appear willing to discuss trade imbalances, as well as buying more natural gas and investing to revitalize the U.S. shipbuilding industry.

Speaking from Washington on Wednesday, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, also said there was no plan to rush into a trade deal with the United States.

Ms. Reeves, who was set to meet with Mr. Bessent, said she wanted to reduce trade barriers between Britain and other countries, but there were firm lines her government would not cross, like changing food or car safety standards.

European officials have expressed frustration about a lack of clear goals from the Trump administration.

Valdis Dombrovskis, the European commissioner responsible for the economy, said on Wednesday at the Semafor World Economy Summit.

E.U. officials have drawn up lists of American products they can put their own tariffs on in retaliation, and are working to diversify their trading relationships.

Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, told a German newspaper last week that she was having “countless talks with heads of state and government around the world who want to work together with us on the new order,” including Iceland, New Zealand, the United Arab Emirates, India, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Mexico.

title: Trump, los aranceles y las trmpas a la economía global - (Published 8 hour(s), 12 minute(s) ago)
content: "En ese contexto, desde el pasado 20 de enero en que Trump asumió la conducción de la nación más poderosa del mundo, se ha embarcado en una guerra comercial, bajo la proclama de la verdadera ...
resumen: Estados Unidos es la economía más grande del mundo, con un PBI de casi US$30 billones. En el comercio mundial representa el 13%. Desde el pasado 20 de enero, cuando Trump asumió la conducción de la nación más poderosa del mundo, se ha embarcado en una guerra comercial, bajo la proclama de la verdadera independencia del coloso del norte, que pasa por el relanzamiento de la manufactura nativa, para superar su déficit comercial; sin embargo, lo que han originado las políticas extremistas aplicadas por el régimen es la pérdida de dinamismo de la economía estadounidense y desequilibrios en la economía mundial. Para JP Morgan, la guerra comercial es suficiente como para llevar la economía mundial a una recesión. Moody’s Ratings señala que los aranceles impuestos probablemente ralentizarán significativamente el crecimiento económico global. No solamente es el impacto de dichas medidas en la producción, en el valor de los bienes y servicios y los mercados bursátiles, sino también el mismo efecto pernicioso de desconfianza e incertidumbre que ha generado nerviosismo en los mercados económicos y financieros. La suspensión temporal de la gran mayoría de los mal llamados aranceles “recíprocos”, tras la caída de las bolsas mundiales y la venta masiva de los bonos estadounidenses, no servirá de mucho, ya que los bruscos movimientos de las bolsas, un importante aumento de la volatilidad, y el repunte de los “spreads” de crédito, reflejan el potencial desestabilizador de las medidas anunciadas. Este aumento de volatilidad, fruto de una mayor sensibilidad de los inversores a las noticias de actualidad y a las disputas arancelarias, seguirá siendo el factor clave que determinará las perspectivas económicas mundiales, con impacto en la inflación y en el crecimiento económico. El PBI de Estados Unidos y China representa US$48 billones, cifra cercana a la mitad del PBI mundial que en 2024 alcanzó los US$110 billones.

title: New York leads 12-state lawsuit against Trump’s tariffs as ‘illegal tax hike’ - (Published 11 hour(s), 18 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump’s reckless tariffs have skyrocketed costs for consumers and unleashed economic chaos across the country." ...
resumen:
Governor Kathy Hochul and Attorney General Letitia James announced that New York and a coalition of 11 other states are suing the Trump Administration for its institution of what they deem “illegal tariffs.”

The lawsuit argues the tariffs imposed on the nation’s trading partners by the Trump Administration will increase unemployment, raise inflation, and threaten Americans’ wages by slowing economic growth.

Hochul and James also said the tariffs will harm the states and their residents by making important goods ranging from electronics to building materials more expensive and scarce.

Hochul said she is partnering with James on this litigation on behalf of New York consumers, “because we can’t let President Trump push our country into a recession.”

The tariffs were issued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

The lawsuit, filed by Attorney General James and a coalition of attorneys general, argues that Congress has not granted the president the authority to impose these tariffs and therefore the administration violated the law by imposing them through executive orders, social media posts, and agency orders.

The coalition seeks a court order halting these IEEPA tariffs, including the worldwide tariffs that were paused on April 9, and preventing the Trump administration from enforcing or implementing them.

Since February, Trump has been ordering tariffs against some of America’s closest trading partners.

The tariffs, which have expanded in a series of announcements in April, now cover nearly every country worldwide, including places that are not involved in international trade, such as the Heard and McDonald Islands.

James said, “Donald Trump promised that he would lower prices and ease the cost of living, but these illegal tariffs will have the exact opposite effect on American families. His tariffs are unlawful and if not stopped, they will lead to more inflation, unemployment, and economic damage.”

Trump issued a statement in an executive order about the tariffs.

The lawsuit, filed in the United States Court of International Trade, asserts that President Trump has no authority to impose tariffs as he has.

The coalition argues in the lawsuit that the law was not designed to allow the president to unilaterally impose worldwide tariffs indiscriminately.

The coalition argues that the Trump administration has overstepped its authority and violated the Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act by imposing these tariffs.

The lawsuit is seeking a court order declaring the Trump administration’s IEEPA tariff orders to be in violation of the law and ordering the administration to stop implementing or enforcing these tariffs.

Economists estimate the increased tariffs will cost the average family thousands of dollars per year.

A report from the New York City Comptroller estimated that even a mild recession caused by the tariffs would lead to over 35,000 lost jobs in New York City alone.

New York state agencies could end up paying over $100 million in extra costs due to tariffs increasing prices, according to Hochul’s office.

Joining Attorney General James in filing this lawsuit are the attorneys general of Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Maine, Minnesota, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, and Vermont.

Hochul said she has been in contact with federal leaders regarding the “devastating effects tariffs will have on New York’s residents, businesses and our economy.”

title: Trade war costs will be more than taxpayer money - (Published 12 hour(s), 39 minute(s) ago)
content: The Trump administration may grant U.S. agriculture special exemptions from parts of its ever-changing tariff regime, but it can’t exempt it from everyday economic reality.
resumen:
The Trump administration may grant U.S. agriculture special exemptions from parts of its ever-changing tariff regime, but it can’t exempt it from everyday economic reality.

The 2025 American ag economy will be on its heels.

According to USDA, 2025′s net farm income will be a slim $137.7 billion, slightly skinnier than last year’s $139.1 billion. Both, however, are miles from 2022′s record of $182 billion.

Congress poured billions into the ag economy last December. Those “supplemental and ad hoc disaster assistance payments,” USDA notes, “are forecast at $35.7 billion … (for) losses due to natural disasters in 2023 and 2024.”

Farmers and ranchers can expect 2025 “federal government direct farm program payments” to be a whopping $42.4 billion.

2020′s record-setting $45.6 billion included the first Trump administration’s $27 billion Market Facilitation Program introduced to soften the effects of its 2018 tariffs that clipped ag exports to China.

This year’s federal “assistance,” explains USDA, will go straight to farmers’ 2025 bottom line and raise the market-generated total from $137.7 billion to a near-record $180.1 billion.

Billions in potential ag exports and billions in future farm program payments are at stake. America’s top five ag buyers — Mexico, Canada, China, the European Union and Japan — accounted for 61% of 2024′s total $191 billion in U.S. ag exports.

China imported $24.7 billion of U.S. ag goods in 2024. This vital U.S. ag market now faces a 104% tariff.

The American ag trade deficit will grow.

The United States turned an ag trade deficit in 2019, the year after the first Trump administration imposed tariffs on China. Since then, the annual deficit has grown; it hit $37 billion in 2024 and is forecast at $49 billion in 2025.

“Ad hoc disaster assistance payments” could easily double from the forecasted $42.4 billion.

If anticipated “trade war” payments simply matched the “market facilitation payments” the first Trump USDA paid farmers in 2018 and 2019, they’d receive another $27 billion.

Today’s far bigger tariff war suggests far bigger payments — $40 billion? $60 billion? More? — to stem the bleeding caused by this self-inflicted trade war.

title: Trump says U.S. will 'get Greenland,' military force may not be needed but not ruled out - (Published 20 hour(s), 32 minute(s) ago)
content: WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump refused on Saturday to take military force off the table in his quest to acquire Greenland, saying he had an obligation to pursue ownership of the Danish ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump did not rule out military force to acquire Greenland in an interview as the Danish territory continued to rebuff his advances.

Trump, in an interview with NBC News, said he'd "absolutely" had conversations about annexing Greenland.

“We’ll get Greenland. Yeah, 100%,” Trump said, according to the news outlet.

Vice President JD Vance accused Denmark of lagging on security and leaving Greenland open to invasion from Russia and China. He encouraged the people of Greenland to break away from Denmark to create space for the United States to have a conversation with the territory about acquiring it.

Vance said he was emphasizing that Trump does not believe military force is needed for the United States to take over Greenland.

Vance said at Pituffik Space Base, "We do not think that military force is ever going to be necessary."

Trump said there's a "good possibility" that the United States can do it without the assistance of the military.

Trump said, "No, I never take military force off the table. But I think there's a good possibility that we could do it without military force. We have an obligation to protect the world. This is world peace, this is international security. And I have that obligation while I'm president. No, I don't take anything off the table."

Vance and U.S. officials, including Trump's national security adviser Michael Waltz, visited the military base.

Vance said Denmark had "underinvested" in the security of Greenland.

Vance said, "Our message to Denmark is very simple. You have not done a good job by the people of Greenland. That has to change. And because it hasn’t changed, this is why President Trump’s policy in Greenland is what it is."

Denmark's foreign minister, Lars Løkke Rasmussen, said in a video on the social media platform formerly known as Twitter that his country can take criticism but does not "appreciate the tone" of the Trump administration's comments about his country.

He invited the United States to work with Denmark to enhance its military presence in Greenland.

Greenland's new prime minister, Jens-Frederik Nielsen, also said the comments showed a "lack of respect" for the island.

Trump said on Friday at the White House, "We need Greenland, very importantly, for international security. We have to have Greenland."

Trump said: "I don’t really think about that. I don’t really care. Greenland’s a very separate subject, very different. It’s international peace. It’s international security and strength."

Trump said Saturday that he still has confidence in his national security team.

Trump told NBC News Saturday, “I don’t fire people because of fake news and because of witch hunts.”

The U.S. president also said he "couldn't care less" if automakers raise vehicle prices because of his 25% tariff on imports.

He also said he would move ahead with far-reaching duties due to take effect April 2 unless affected countries offer him something in return.

Trump said, "Only if people are willing to give us something of great value. Because countries have things of great value, otherwise, there's no room for negotiation."

title: Trump Crashing The Dollar Is Wrecking Japan’s 2025, Too - (Published 16 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: For 20-plus years now, U.S. officials have been prodding Japan to engineer a stronger yen. It never occurred to Tokyo, though, that Washington might be willing to crash the dollar to do it.
resumen: Three months into the Donald Trump 2.0 presidency, the administration’s trade war, policy chaos, and general dysfunction have investors fleeing the dollar. The dollar is down nearly 10% versus the yen and euro. President Trump’s team believes a weaker exchange rate will offset the effects of the tariffs. The Federal Reserve is slashing rates. The resulting turmoil in stock and bond markets has triggered a sell-America dynamic in global markets. Trump’s tariffs have markets betting on stagflation in Asia’s second-biggest economy. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is stepping away from plans to tighten next week. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda has been plotting an escape from 25 years of zero interest rates and quantitative easing. In July 2024, Team Ueda managed to get the benchmark rate to 0.25%. In January, the BOJ reached a 17-year high of 0.5%. At its April 30-May 1 policy meeting, the BOJ was widely expected to boost rates to 0.75%. Trump’s one-man tariff arms race will keep the BOJ on hold. The collateral damage from his 145% tax on China, 25% levy on the auto industry, and tariffs on steel and aluminum may push Japanese rates back to zero. The yen’s surge, thanks to a cratering dollar, could devastate corporate profits, deepening losses for a Nikkei 225 Stock Average down nearly 12% this year. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is having a decent week versus Peter Navarro. Trump’s longest-held economic views include his 1980s-drenched belief that Asia is stealing U.S. jobs, wealth, and America’s future and must be stopped. The U.S. is only China’s third biggest market after Southeast Asia and Europe. The dollar and U.S. Treasury securities are the central nervous system of global trade and finance. International Monetary Fund Chief Economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas says the global economy is being "severely tested” by the Trump 2.0 trade war. The IMF slashed its global growth forecast this year to 2.8% from 3.3%. The Institute of International Finance thinks the U.S. will shrink an annualized 0.8% in the third quarter and 0.3% in the fourth.
