title: ‘Chaotic’ tariff regime and trade war are leaving small businesses in their wake - (Published 19 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Small businesses are the backbone of the US economy, homegrown companies that would seem to be exactly what President Donald Trump aims to protect as part of his “America First” trade agenda. But for ...
resumen:
Melanie Abrantes turns a cork vase for her sustainable home goods collection made with Portuguese cork in her Oakland, California, studio in 2020.

Small businesses are the backbone of the US economy.

For many small business owners, the years of hard work and the optimistic outlooks have unraveled seemingly overnight.

Katharine Burke's self-care Purryfuls products went into production the first week of April.

The first week of April also brought massive tariffs for imported goods from China, where Burke’s products are made.

Melanie Abrantes, now 11 years in at running her eponymous handcrafted product design company, has found herself in need of ordering more artisan tools, cork and other raw materials to support the steadily growing subscription carving club.

For Busy Baby owner Beth Fynbo Benike, 2025 was stacking up to be a growth-spurt year for the business she started in 2017.

The Army veteran’s baby products company got its foot in the door at Walmart and Target, and she just placed her largest-ever order to replenish inventory for her website and Amazon.

That container of goods, however, now will cost her nearly $230,000 to arrive on US soil.

The erratic nature of President Donald Trump’s trade policies and the severity of newly imposed tariffs have wreaked havoc on small businesses in the US, causing costs to quickly skyrocket, unsettling longstanding supply chains, swiftly stifling growth and expansion plans — and threatening to kill American-bred businesses.

“I’m fully leveraged against this, and the first thought that came to my head is, ‘I’m going to lose my house. My boys are not going to have a place to live,’” Benike said.

Beth Fynbo Benike, founder of Busy Baby, in the warehouse that houses the baby products she sells, in Zumbrota, Minnesota in April.

These and other small businesses say they’re caught in the crossfire of escalating trade wars.

They’ve had to rely on imported goods because the ability to source and produce domestically is not feasible and, in many cases, nonexistent.

Burke ultimately turned to a China-based manufacturer to help design, test and manufacture her purring cat self-care plushies for adults.

Economists have warned that the sharpest escalation in the US tariff rate in more than 115 years comes with cascading negative economic consequences, including higher costs, rising inflation and gashed earnings that may lead to a pullback in spending that could cause businesses to fail, unemployment to rise and a recession to grip the US.

America’s small businesses could be the canaries in the coal mine.

Small businesses typically have minimal wiggle room in their margins and can’t simply eat the added costs like the big guys can.

Capital isn’t as easy to come by, making small businesses more vulnerable and susceptible to exogenous threats.

Small businesses with fewer than 50 workers employ nearly half of the American labor force and serve as critical drivers of employment economic growth.

Burke has spent the past two years building her business and creating Purryfuls, a purring plushie that’s intended to help stressed-out Millennials and Gen Zers.

Burke decided to create a self-care product instead (basing the design on Wren) and last month launched Purryfuls at the New York Toy Fair.

After landing some acclaim and a slew of pre-orders, Burke pulled the trigger on the production.

The first line of Purryfuls was being crafted the same week that Trump’s massive “Liberation Day” tariffs were implemented — and duties on Chinese imports quickly skyrocketed to 145%.

Burke said she’s worried that the tariffs could shut down her business before it even gets going.

Burke has no option but to move full steam ahead and hope for the best — even though she doesn’t yet know how much more she’ll have to shell out when her 1,000 Purryfuls units land at the Port of Los Angeles.

When Trump announced a 90-day pause on the steep and varying “reciprocal” tariffs for dozens of US trading partners (while keeping in place a 10% across-the-board tariff), that gave a slight reprieve for Abrantes, an Oakland, California-based designer who imports carving tools from Japanese artisans and raw materials from countries like Portugal, where cork is plentiful.

Costs are already starting to rise for the business, she said, noting that her US-based packaging supplier sources some materials from China and has had to raise prices.

Abrantes has yet to do so herself, although she recently posted a warning on Instagram that she’d have to pass along any costs from the larger tariffs.

Everything seemed to be falling into place for Busy Baby, a company that specializes in products that keep babies’ items from falling on the floor.

In the fall of 2024, the Oronoco, Minnesota-based company inked deals with Target and Walmart to sell tethered baby place mats and other accessories at 250 stores across the US.

Benike ordered a containerful of product from her longtime manufacturer in China.

That $158,000 order (which has been already paid for) is sitting in her manufacturer’s warehouse 7,500 miles away.

If it were to get shipped to the US, Busy Baby would have to pay an additional $229,100 to cover the 145% tariff expense.

Benike launched a crowdfunding campaign to help her try to cover the cost.

The Walmart and Target contracts were signed when tariffs were 0% and the terms include locked-in pricing.

The container in waiting is for summer inventory.

The next Busy Baby order would be for the critical holiday season.

About 40% of annual sales come during the fourth quarter.

She’s exploring all options including shifting her sales to countries outside of the US.

She’s also reaching out to members of Congress to share the plight of her business and other small operations, which she feels have been cast aside, especially as exemptions were made for smartphone, electronics and computers — products critical to the bottom line of Big Tech firms, including those not founded in America.

title: India and the new world disorder - (Published Apr 20, 2025)
content: Opening Pakistan’s borders could revive textiles, cement, and agriculture, tapping into the billion-plus market next door.
resumen: The escalating United States-China rivalry is reshaping the global order. India is leveraging its market size and reforms to grow its global clout, while Pakistan faces economic challenges. Globalisation is unravelling as a populist Trump pursues a neo-isolationist path. Deglobalisation is inherently inflationary. Tariffs indicate a deeper economic dislocation. Opening Pakistan’s borders could revive textiles, cement, and agriculture. The US-China trade war has intensified, with China halting exports of key rare earths. Economist Lawrence Summers warns that tariff-driven chaos risks “economic instability”. India continues to be the fastest-growing major economy. The US-China rift has driven multinationals to diversify supply chains, and India has lured giants like Apple. In 2023-24, Foxconn and Wistron produced $14 billion in iPhones, with Apple aiming to shift 25 per cent of its global output to India by 2027, up from 5pc in 2020. Foreign direct investment (FDI) equity inflows reached $44.4bn in FY24. The US is deepening ties with India, viewing it as a strategic counterweight to China. Bilateral trade hit $129.2bn in 2024, with India exporting $87.4bn and importing $41.8bn. The Quad alliance (US, India, Japan, Australia) counters China’s Indo-Pacific ambitions. US investments in India’s tech and defence sectors cement this partnership. India’s trade with China reached $118.4bn in FY24, skewed towards imports ($101.7bn) over exports ($16.67bn). Initiatives like “Make in India” and Digital India have propelled IT exports past $200bn in 2024, with mobile phone exports at $15bn, aided by US tariffs on Chinese goods (29pc in 2025). India’s 570 million internet users drive its digital economy, the world’s third-largest by purchasing power parity. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) projects 7pc GDP growth through 2030. India’s 3pc share of global manufacturing in 2023 trails China’s 32pc. India’s tariffs, raised to shield local industries, align with deglobalisation’s rise. India is negotiating missile sales to Southeast Asia, advancing the Middle East Europe Economic Corridor, and balancing US and China ties. Pakistan’s story contrasts starkly. The China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) delivered infrastructure projects, but these came at a steep cost. Trade with Beijing hit $20bn in 2024, dwarfing $7.7bn with the US. Pakistan’s economy faces steep challenges. Textiles, 60pc of exports, struggle with high energy costs and outdated tech. FDI declined to $1.8bn in 2023-24, compared to India’s $44.4bn. The World Economic Forum ranks Pakistan 107th in competitiveness. World Bank’s Martin Raiser warned, “Pakistan’s economy is stuck in a low-growth trap, with poor human development and rising poverty.”. In April 2025, Army Chief General Asim Munir met a US congressional delegation. Regional integration, especially trade with India, could help Pakistan grow faster. Historical tensions kept commerce negligible. India must accelerate reforms. Strengthening ties with the EU and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) can reduce dependence on US-China dynamics. India’s strategic balance between Washington and Beijing cements its place in a multipolar world. Pakistan faces a tougher climb. Reviving the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (Saarc) or exploring the Indian trade could anchor it regionally. Deglobalisation’s pressures add urgency to these reforms. The US-China rivalry tests South Asia. In this new world disorder, economics trumps geography.

content: Madrid, 21 abr (EFECOM).- La multinacional española de agua y energía Cox ha anunciado este lunes la adquisición de Solar Pro, una planta solar de 24 megavatios (MW) en Panamá con un contrato de ...
resumen: La multinacional española de agua y energía Cox anunció la adquisición de Solar Pro, una planta solar de 24 megavatios (MW) en Panamá. La inversión asciende a 20 millones de dólares, con un 'project finance' del 80 %, unos 16 millones, asegurado por un banco local. Solar Pro está conformado por dos plantas solares de 12 MW cada una -Solar Pro I y Solar Pro II-, ambas ya en plena operación desde principios de este año. El proyecto aportará energía limpia a unas 10.000 viviendas y permitirá un ahorro estimado de 24.500 toneladas de dióxido de carbono (CO₂) al año. El proyecto cuenta con un PPA dolarizado a diez años con un 'offtaker' o comprador de la energía calificado con grado de inversión BBB+ por Fitch Ratings.

title: De la hegemonía liberal al autoritarismo híbrido: Trump y el cambio de paradigma internacional, por Manuel Rodríguez Cuadros - (Published 11 hour(s), 40 minute(s) ago)
content: De la hegemonía liberal al autoritarismo híbrido: Trump y el cambio de paradigma internacional, por Manuel Rodríguez Cuadros ...
resumen: La democracia liberal de Estados Unidos está siendo afectada. Trump gobierna mediante órdenes ejecutivas, minimizando el papel del Congreso. Ha desacreditado a la Corte Suprema y ha sugerido su ampliación. Existe un enfrentamiento por el caso de la repatriación de Kilmar Ábrego García, deportado erróneamente a El Salvador. La Corte Suprema ha confirmado su repatriación inmediata y la administración se ha negado a acatar la sentencia. La administración ha desfinanciado los organismos de control, ha acusado de traición a opositores y ha restringido los derechos de prensa y protesta. La violación de los derechos humanos de muchos de los deportados y sus familias empieza a tornarse sistemática. El régimen político norteamericano podría estar transitando hacia una situación en la que se afecten la separación de poderes, la pluralidad democrática y la vigencia de derechos humanos básicos, derivando en un régimen político híbrido. La política general de Trump, del "America First", podría ser asimilada y aplicada en un entorno institucional democrático, pero su instrumento es el ejercicio autoritario del poder. La reestructuración del poder mundial impulsada por la Casa Blanca está tratando de imponer un régimen basado en la unilateralidad del ejercicio del poder, que menoscaba la legalidad y la institucionalidad internacional, y que se sustenta en la correlación de fuerzas. La afectación de normas esenciales del Estado democrático a nivel interno se refleja en la imposición de una gobernanza autoritaria en la escena internacional, que socava el derecho internacional, las Naciones Unidas y la institucionalidad multilateral. Trump propicia un régimen mundial unipolar e híbrido. El uso de los aranceles como herramienta de poder, con un arancel general unilateral del 10 % como mínimo, y la imposición unilateral de escalas arancelarias según cada país, han liquidado la liberalización del comercio. La guerra comercial contemporánea representa un cambio doctrinal. Lo que Trump está operando es una política de poder geoeconómico. La economía mundial está fragmentándose en bloques. Los aranceles, las sanciones, las exclusiones tecnológicas, los embargos, las “listas negras” de empresas y los acuerdos bilaterales impuestos se ejercen como mecanismos de coerción. Se afectará seriamente la tasa de crecimiento global. Los aranceles disciplinan actores, reorganizan cadenas de suministro, castigan rivales y recompensan aliados. Se ha intensificado la presión sobre empresas que producen en China para que se relocalicen en EE.UU., especialmente en sectores clave como tecnología, defensa, farmacéutica y energías críticas. En Gaza, los bombardeos masivos y las represalias continúan con total impunidad, con la ONU paralizada por el veto sistemático de EE.UU. y la retórica de "legítima defensa". Las sanciones internacionales ya no se aplican por consenso, sino por iniciativa de las políticas de poder. El derecho internacional está siendo marginado, las organizaciones multilaterales debilitadas y las relaciones entre Estados regidas por la fuerza relativa. Lo que emerge es un mundo sin reglas universales, pero con jerarquías funcionales. Estados Unidos se han retirado del Acuerdo de París sobre el cambio climático, del Tratado de Cielos Abiertos, de la Organización Mundial de la Salud, del Consejo de Derechos Humanos; han dejado de financiar el Fondo para los Refugiados Palestinos (UNRWA); se han excluido unilateralmente del sistema de solución de controversias de la OMC; han congelado el pago de sus cuotas a Naciones Unidas y excluyen todo espacio multilateral en las negociaciones de paz en Ucrania. La administración Trump ha vetado resoluciones relativas a Palestina, Ucrania y el cambio climático, y ha amenazado con retirarse del Consejo de Seguridad. Hay un abandono de los espacios sociales de la agenda internacional para el desarrollo. Marco Rubio ha declarado que “Estados Unidos ya no asumirá la carga de proporcionar la mayoría de la ayuda humanitaria global”. Una de las decisiones más controversiales ha sido la supresión de USAID, lo que ha derivado en la cancelación de programas vitales de salud, alimentación y educación en países como Haití, Honduras, Etiopía y Yemen. En el ámbito migratorio, la política de deportaciones masivas ha generado la expulsión acelerada de personas sin el respeto al debido proceso. En casos como el de El Salvador, migrantes deportados son arrestados inmediatamente al aterrizar. Se han deteriorado los derechos fundamentales de inmigrantes, mujeres, personas LGBTI y comunidades afroamericanas. La política exterior de Trump representa una transformación estratégica profunda: el paso de una hegemonía liberal, basada en reglas e instituciones multilaterales, hacia una dominación híbrida en la que prevalece la correlación de fuerzas, la imposición unilateral y la selectividad normativa. La doctrina que guía este viraje ya no reconoce la universalidad del derecho, sino que privilegia la lógica del interés nacional sostenido por la capacidad coercitiva del Estado.

title: China está encontrando maneras de reemplazar a los agricultores estadounidenses - (Published 13 hour(s), 48 minute(s) ago)
content: China ha dependido durante mucho tiempo de Estados Unidos para la soja. Pero con los nuevos aranceles elevados, es probable que recurra aún más a Brasil y Argentina ...
resumen:
China está encontrando maneras de reemplazar a los agricultores estadounidenses. China ha dependido durante mucho tiempo de Estados Unidos para la soja. Con los nuevos aranceles elevados, es probable que recurra aún más a Brasil y Argentina.

Estados Unidos vende más soja a China, en valor, que cualquier otro producto. El año pasado, esto ascendió a más de 27 millones de toneladas métricas, con un valor de 12.800 millones de dólares, o aproximadamente 9 centavos de cada dólar de bienes que Estados Unidos vendió a China.

Con los enormes aranceles impuestos entre ambos países en las últimas dos semanas, es probable que esas ventas se vean afectadas pronto. Esto es una mala noticia para los agricultores estadounidenses que cultivan soja y para los criadores de pollos y cerdos chinos que la compran, y potencialmente una muy buena noticia para Brasil.

Más de la mitad de las exportaciones estadounidenses de soja se destinaron a China el año pasado, pero el precio acaba de subir un 135 % debido a los aranceles que China impuso en respuesta al impuesto del 145 % del presidente Trump a las importaciones chinas.

Los productores estadounidenses de soja están preocupados por si su principal cliente seguirá comprando.

Los dos países sudamericanos (Brasil y Argentina) producen el 52 % de la soja mundial, incluyendo el 40 % proveniente solo de Brasil, en comparación con el 28 % de Estados Unidos.

Neusa Lopes, alta ejecutiva de Girassol Agrícola, un importante productor de soja en el mayor estado sojero de Brasil, Mato Grosso, dijo que si China no puede obtenerla de Estados Unidos, tendrá que adquirirla más de Brasil.

La Sra. Lopes, cuya empresa cultiva soja y maíz en más de 70.000 hectáreas, dijo que ahora podía vender un saco de 60 kilos de soja por unos 21 dólares, un 10 % más que el mes pasado. La mayor parte de su cosecha se destina a China, que ya es, con diferencia, el mayor comprador de soja de Brasil.

André Nassar, presidente de la Asociación Brasileña de Productores de Aceites Vegetales, que representa a los mayores productores de soja del país, dijo que la temporada de cosecha está terminando en Sudamérica y ya han vendido casi tres cuartas partes de sus existencias.

Heather Feuerstein, dueña de una granja cerca de Grand Rapids, Michigan, debe comenzar a sembrar sus más de 80 hectáreas pronto. Si trabaja duro, el clima acompaña y se controlan los insectos, a finales del otoño cosechará 10.000 bushels o más, más de 270.000 kilos de soja.

Los productores estadounidenses de soja afirman que no pueden hacer mucho más que plantar y esperar que todo salga bien.

Organizaciones como el Consejo de Exportación de Soja de EE. UU. y la Asociación Americana de la Soja intentan desarrollar mercados más amplios en países como India, Egipto y México.

China ha invertido dinero en almacenes, ferrocarriles, puertos y otras infraestructuras en Brasil durante la última década para poder transportar más soja del país a bordo de barcos chinos.

Cofco, el gigante alimentario estatal chino, está detrás del proyecto de una terminal en el puerto más grande de Latinoamérica, en Santos, Brasil, de casi 500 millones de dólares.

El viceministro de agricultura chino se reunió con los principales funcionarios agrícolas de Brasil. El presidente brasileño, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, anunció que viajará a Pekín para reunirse con su homólogo chino, Xi Jinping, el próximo mes.

Durante su primer gobierno, el Sr. Trump inició una guerra comercial contra China, de la cual los productores de soja brasileños se beneficiaron. Desde 2017, justo antes de dicha guerra comercial, hasta el año pasado, China aumentó sus importaciones anuales de soja brasileña un 35 %, hasta 72,5 millones de toneladas métricas, mientras que redujo las importaciones de soja estadounidense un 14 %, hasta 27 millones de toneladas métricas, según datos de ambos países.

Lo único que evitó la ruina de los agricultores estadounidenses durante la última guerra comercial fue un programa de rescate gubernamental de 23 000 millones de dólares. La administración Trump vuelve a contemplar un rescate agrícola.

title: - (Published 16 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: In a statement today, the credit rating agency said while the Trump administration's 90-day pause of "reciprocal" tariffs (announced on April 2) offers some reprieve for Asia-Pacific economies, the ...
resumen:
Asia-Pacific credit conditions remain firmly on the downside, given the escalation in China-US relations and uncertain US trade policy, which are hitting growth and confidence in the region, said S&P Global Ratings.

The Trump administration's 90-day pause of "reciprocal" tariffs (announced on April 2) offers some reprieve for Asia-Pacific economies, but the region is not out of the woods.

The April 2 tariffs affected Asia-Pacific the most. This reflects the prevalence of large bilateral trade surpluses with the US across most countries.

The threat and imposition of tariffs by the US continue to loom over global trade and economic growth and could also reignite US consumer inflation.

Confidence is set to deteriorate further amid halts in new business investments and worsening household sentiment.

Equity and debt markets are likely to stay volatile. Taken together, these economic, consumer, and financial market developments are negative for Asia-Pacific and global credit.

The strained US-China relations will affect Asia-Pacific economies, given the region's integrated trade ties with both countries.

A sharper deterioration in China-US relations will further strain confidence, and severely disrupt supply chains and global trade flows.

These events could spur a sharper global slowdown. These rapid developments have prompted us to raise our assessment of the global trade risk to very high.

For the rest of Asia-Pacific, the partial tariff reprieve broadly cushions current growth assumptions.

Small and trade-centric economies (such as Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore, and Taiwan) may face greater obstacles to growth.

Locally produced goods in Asia-Pacific and outside the US could face more intense price competition as Chinese exporters scout new markets and cut prices to accelerate sales.

A redirection of products into regional markets would further squeeze domestic markets or sectors with excess capacity and this could stoke further escalation of protectionist measures within Asia-Pacific.

title: Los 100 primeros días del tercer mandato de Maduro en ocho puntos - (Published 10 hour(s), 49 minute(s) ago)
content: Nicolás Maduro llegó este domingo a los primeros 100 días de su controvertido tercer mandato en Venezuela, marcados por cuestionamientos a su legitimidad, sanciones y el retorno de más de 2.500 migran ...
resumen:
Los 100 primeros días del tercer mandato de Maduro en ocho puntos:

1.  Nicolás Maduro llegó a los primeros 100 días de su tercer mandato en Venezuela, marcados por cuestionamientos a su legitimidad, sanciones y el retorno de más de 2.500 migrantes, en su gran mayoría deportados por Estados Unidos.
2.  Cuestionamientos: Maduro fue proclamado ganador por el Consejo Nacional Electoral (CNE), que controlan rectores afines al chavismo. El Centro Carter concluyó en febrero que estas elecciones “no pueden considerarse democráticas”. La Plataforma Unitaria Democrática (PUD) denunció un “golpe de Estado”, al insistir en que el vencedor fue Edmundo González Urrutia.
3.  Apoyo y rechazo internacional: Maduro es respaldado por países como Rusia, China, Irán, Turquía, Catar, Bielorrusia, Serbia, Guinea Ecuatorial, Cuba, Nicaragua, Bolivia, Honduras y San Vicente y las Granadinas. EE.UU., Canadá, Argentina, Chile, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Panamá, Paraguay, Perú, Colombia, Brasil, República Dominicana, Uruguay, Reino Unido, Ucrania, Alemania, Italia y Japón, entre otros, han cuestionado su legitimidad.
4.  Trump vs. Maduro: Washington endureció las sanciones contra Caracas tras el retorno de Donald Trump a la Casa Blanca, con el fin de las licencias petroleras y la decisión de imponer aranceles del 25 % a los compradores de crudo venezolano, así como tarifas del 15 % a productos de la nación caribeña. Maduro decretó un estado de emergencia económica en respuesta a las medidas de Washington. Caracas emitió una “alerta de viaje” sobre “riesgos” en EE.UU.
5.  Migración: Desde febrero, 2.559 venezolanos han retornado a su país -la mayoría desde EE.UU.-, en 13 vuelos, tres de ellos en aviones del país norteamericano, como parte de un acuerdo alcanzado en una visita de Richard Grenell a Caracas en enero. Maduro denunció una “agresión civilizatoria” contra migrantes en EE.UU., que en marzo deportó a más de 200 personas a El Salvador, acusadas de supuestamente pertenecer a la banda criminal de origen venezolano Tren de Aragua.
6.  Próximas elecciones: Maduro aseguró que este año habrá, al menos, una decena de comicios, entre ellos, los regionales y parlamentarios, que se celebrarán el 25 de mayo. El chavismo prevé someter a consulta un proyecto de reforma constitucional que elabora una comisión encabezada por el fiscal general, Tarek William Saab, y que deberá ser presentado en mayo.
7.  Esequibo: La tensión con Guyana se ha exacerbado con los planes de Caracas de elegir “por primera vez al gobernador” de la Guayana Esequiba. Georgetown pidió a la Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ) emitir medidas para exigir a Venezuela “no celebrar elecciones en ninguna parte del territorio guyanés”. La Administración de Maduro ha denunciado acciones de Guyana “en alianza con (la petrolera estadounidense) ExxonMobil” en la zona marítima “pendiente por delimitar”.
8.  Economía: Desde el 10 de enero, la moneda local se ha devaluado un 33 % frente al dólar en el mercado oficial. El Observatorio Venezolano de Finanzas (OVF) registró una inflación acumulada del 36,1 % en el primer trimestre. Sindicalistas y trabajadores exigen un aumento del salario mínimo, que equivale a 1,60 dólares mensuales.
9.  Derechos humanos: Familiares de detenidos considerados presos políticos han llevado a cabo numerosas protestas. La ONG Foro Penal computaba hasta esta semana 890 personas arrestadas por motivos políticos -cinco de ellas adolescentes-, 807 menos respecto al balance publicado el pasado 10 de enero.

title: Impactos de medidas de Trump sobre el Perú - (Published 14 hour(s), 10 minute(s) ago)
content: “Sea como sea, la incertidumbre causada por Trump a la economía mundial es veneno. Periodos similares de la historia económica generan contracciones de las economías”.
resumen:
Las medidas arancelarias y la postura de Trump frente al mundo afectarán al Perú a través de dos vías: el impacto directo de los aranceles y la desaceleración económica mundial.

Los aranceles directos pueden afectar más a la agroindustria y textiles. El kilo de arándanos o de uvas podría subir de 20 a 22 dólares (asumiendo un arancel del 10%). La ropa hecha con algodón pima suele ir a segmentos socioeconómicos más pudientes, que seguirán comprando pese al aumento del precio.

Las tensiones comerciales y la incertidumbre reducen el comercio y la inversión, desacelerando la economía mundial. Se están revisando proyecciones de crecimiento económico mundial a la baja: de 2.6% antes de Trump a 1.5% aproximadamente o, peor aún, 1.0%, como sostiene la ONU.

China y Estados Unidos producen el 44% de la producción mundial. El principal comprador de la producción de los Estados Unidos es China y el principal comprador de la producción china es Estados Unidos. La desaceleración del comercio entre ambas economías reducirá el crecimiento entre ambas. Esto afectará al Perú, que solo produce el 0.3% de la producción mundial.

China le vendió a los Estados Unidos en 2024 por 440,000 millones de dólares. Los aranceles en juguetes se mantienen en 145%. China podría buscar otros mercados, como Perú, lo que supondría una inundación de productos.

title: What do Trump's tariffs mean for Florida's real estate industry? | Opinion - (Published 15 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: The National Association of Home Builders estimates that tariffs could add over $9,200 to the price of an average new single-family home.
resumen: Tariffs on construction materials are not new, but the current situation is different due to its scale and unpredictability. Tariffs are being applied broadly, impacting nearly every product used by builders and homeowners that isn’t entirely domestically made. Imported materials play a vital role in residential construction, with roughly 10% of materials used in homebuilding being imported. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) estimates that tariffs could add over $9,200 to the price of an average new single-family home, while Zelman & Associates forecasts this figure could climb as high as $25,000 in some markets. Higher renovation costs will discourage homeowners from investing in improvements. For builders, especially those focused on mid-market or entry-level housing, these material cost hikes can be deal breakers. Another potential impact of tariffs may be felt in mortgage rates. Canadians account for approximately 11% of all foreign homebuyers in the U.S., with Florida consistently ranked as their top destination. Recent trade tensions have left many Canadians feeling unwelcome.

title: Guangzhou sufre por la guerra comercial, pero reta a Trump: “China va a ganar” - (Published 22 hour(s), 54 minute(s) ago)
content: La capital de la provincia de Cantón, en el sur del país, es un importante centro manufacturero; muchas de sus fábricas han pausado los envíos a Estados Unidos ...
resumen: En Guangzhou, China, se siente el impacto de la guerra comercial, especialmente en distritos manufactureros como Panyu. Lily Liao, dueña de Guangzhou Dawang Garment, reporta una caída de pedidos a Estados Unidos de 100,000 dólares mensuales a cero. Otras ocho fábricas chinas consultadas confirman la pausa o cancelación de envíos a Estados Unidos. El señor Wang, fundador de Guangshen, detuvo los envíos a Estados Unidos por primera vez en 21 años, representando entre el 10% y 15% de sus ventas. Los fletes de China a Estados Unidos cayeron un 64% entre la última semana de marzo y la primera de abril, según Vizion. Lily Liao, de origen taiwanés, instalada en Guangzhou desde principios de los 2000, tuvo que reducir un 70% su negocio con Estados Unidos en 2018. Los aranceles estadounidenses han subido hasta un 145% y los chinos hasta un 125%. Liao estima una pérdida del 25% de facturación desde el año pasado. En Panyu, hay más de 7,200 empresas de confección y 27,000 de venta de prendas. El golpe de Trump también afectó a plataformas de moda rápida como Shein. Un taller familiar de botones reporta una caída del 20% en pedidos, y otro de plisados elásticos, un descenso del 50%. Luo Weijun, dueño de un taller, nota una disminución del 5% en los pedidos. En la provincia de Cantón, hay casi 74,000 empresas industriales que facturan más de 20 millones de yuanes (2,4 millones de euros). En la feria de importación y exportación de Cantón, Tracy, de la empresa Aiken, espera que "China va a ganar". Alejandro Jiménez, de Miami, busca nuevas vías de suministro. Longhua, con más de 500 trabajadores, ha sufrido un zarpazo considerable, con Estados Unidos representando cerca del 43% de sus ventas, más de 39 millones de dólares (34 millones de euros). Jianguo Qu, de Longhua, dice que si los aranceles siguen subiendo, venderán a otros países. Steven Selikoff, comerciante, cree que es el mejor momento para visitar China.

title: ‘A Huge Negative Shock’: Three Experts Game Out Recession Odds and Economic Uncertainty - (Published 16 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: Sen: The question when it comes to longer-term rates (like 10- or 30-year yields) is whether investors would see rate cuts as because of judicious monetary policy or pressure from the president. If it ...
resumen:
Josh Barro hosted a written online conversation with Lael Brainard, the director of the National Economic Council from 2023 to 2025 and a former vice chair of the Federal Reserve, and Conor Sen, a columnist for Bloomberg Opinion, to discuss the risks to and uncertainty in Donald Trump’s economy.

The S&P 500 is down about 14 percent from its peak in February.

Markets were hoping for tax cuts and deregulation, but what was received were spending cuts and fiscal uncertainty created by the Department of Government Efficiency, and then a level of tariffs much higher than anyone expected.

The 10 percent base-line tariff for all countries, the 25 percent sectoral tariffs for cars and other products, the enormous tariffs against China mean huge increases in prices for American working families — for clothing, shoes, cars, housing. These are levels similar to the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930, and they are going to hurt families and businesses, costing them $3,000 or more a year, scramble business supply chains and hit the economy.

U.S. Treasury bond yields have risen, and the dollar has weakened compared with other major currencies.

The tariff announcements coming from the White House are raising questions about whether it is a smart bet for global investors to have so much of their money in U.S. assets.

If the strategy is to make the U.S. into more of an exporting country, it is not a smart strategy. Hitting working families with huge price hikes, raising the risk of throwing the economy into a recession, increasing interest costs on the U.S. debt at a time when the administration is planning to issue trillions of dollars of additional debt for tax cuts seems like a self-inflicted mistake.

Putting tariffs on not just final but intermediate goods as well raises the cost of production for U.S. manufacturers.

It would take an enormous permanent shift in the global landscape to fundamentally alter the dollar’s reserve currency status.

Interest rates have been volatile.

The president has reiterated his call for the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates.

The high tariffs imposed by the White House will raise prices for businesses and consumers and contribute to a slowdown in the economy — and that could put Fed policy in a tight spot.

The Fed has two key objectives: keep inflation low and support strong employment.

The administration may say the Fed should cut rates.

Most people think it would be a real mistake for the administration to terminate the Federal Reserve chair before the end of the statutory term (in May 2026).

Businesses cannot predict the tax regime they will operate under, they cannot predict the cost or availability of financing, so they can’t make sound decisions about how to expand or hire.

A recession will be entirely self-inflicted, given that the United States started the year from a position of enviable strength with inflation that has been coming down, strong growth and very good employment.

The easiest dynamic to think about at the moment is this is a shock to the goods economy and supply chains, somewhat similar to what was seen during and after the Covid-19 pandemic.

It is important for Congress to restore the guardrails.

Strategically targeted tariffs are an important part of a strategy that makes sure America can compete fairly in key industries. But it is also important to provide investment incentives.

It doesn’t make any sense to impose high tariffs on countries and products across the board — it just puts an enormous price hike on American working families that can afford it the least, disadvantages U.S. businesses that rely on some imported inputs and risks a recession for no benefit to the United States.

Americans are unhappy about high prices. Tariffs are going to raise prices and lead to less product availability for U.S. consumers.

The surge in consumer inflation expectations is notable.

The debt ceiling standoff and sequester in 2011 between President Barack Obama and Republicans in Congress that cut spending across the board at a time when unemployment was high, inflation was low and the economy was still struggling to recover from the 2008 Great Recession was particularly moronic.

The likelihood of the United States going into recession has increased materially.

The economy started out the year very strong, so it would be malpractice to see a self-inflicted recession.

Every C.E.O. now needs to budget and plan for a recession, which means less hiring and less investment than they budgeted for a month ago.

The consensus is 50-50 odds of a recession.

title: Vance set to visit India for bilateral talks on economic, trade and geopolitical ties - (Published 9 hour(s), 50 minute(s) ago)
content: A trade deal between India and the U.S. could significantly enhance economic ties between the two countries and possibly strengthen diplomatic ties.
resumen: Vice President JD Vance will visit India for four days starting Monday. He will meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi for talks on the economy, trade, and geopolitical ties. The visit is seen as an important diplomatic mission by President Donald Trump’s administration. A trade deal between India and the U.S. could significantly enhance economic ties. The U.S. is India’s largest trading partner, with bilateral trade valued at $190 billion until recently. The visit will “provide an opportunity for both sides to review the progress in bilateral relations” and two leaders will “exchange views on regional and global developments of mutual interest.” Vance’s arrival comes weeks after Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard was in India and two months after Modi met Trump in Washington. Modi hailed a “mega partnership” with the U.S. and kickstarted a negotiation process to minimise the possible fallout of Trump’s tariffs. Trump targeted India with a 26% levy. Modi said he was open to reducing more tariffs on U.S. goods, repatriating undocumented Indian nationals and buying military gear. The two countries also agreed to start talks towards clinching the bilateral trade agreement. Modi spoke with Elon Musk and said they “discussed the immense potential for collaboration in the areas of technology and innovation.” India is a close partner of the U.S. for bilateral trade, foreign direct investments, defence cooperation, and an important strategic ally in combating the rising influence of China in the Indo-Pacific region. It is also part of the Quad, which is made up of the United States plus India, Japan and Australia. Leading U.S companies such as Apple Inc. and Google have expanded operations in India in recent years. Last month, Musk's Starlink entered into agreements with two of India’s top telecom operators. The U.S. and India have set an ambitious target of more than doubling their bilateral trade to $500 billion by 2030 under the expected trade deal agreement. The negotiations are especially urgent for New Delhi as it could be hit hard by Trump’s reciprocal tariffs, particularly in sectors of agriculture, processed food, auto components, high-end machinery, medical equipment and jewelry. Modi and Trump already share rapport. India will purchase more oil, energy and defence equipment, including the fifth-generation stealth fighter jets, from the U.S. The U.S wants greater market access for its agricultural and dairy products in India. Vance’s wife Usha Vance, a practising Hindu, is the daughter of immigrants from South India. Vance will be accompanied by Usha, their children and other senior members of the U.S. administration, and the couple will visit Indian cities of Jaipur and Agra.

title: Trump Tariffs Live Updates: Trump says US having 'nice conversations' with China - (Published 15 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: Donald Trump and Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni expressed confidence about the prospects of a US-EU trade deal, si ...
resumen:
*   Donald Trump and Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni expressed confidence about a US-EU trade deal.
*   Meloni positioned herself as the European leader best placed to defuse Trump’s trade war.
*   Trump declared, “There will be a trade deal, 100 percent.”
*   Meloni said she was “sure” a deal could be reached.
*   Trump called the Italian leader “fantastic.”
*   Meloni, 48, emphasized their alignment on conservative values—especially on immigration and opposition to “woke” ideology—saying, “The goal for me is to make the West great again, and I think we can do it together.”
*   Meloni is the first European leader to visit Trump since he imposed 20% tariffs on EU exports.
*   Though the tariffs have been paused for 90 days, negotiations are ongoing.
*   Meloni said Trump accepted an invitation to Rome and might meet other European leaders there.
*   India and the United States are set to begin a three-day round of trade talks in Washington starting April 23, aiming to lay the groundwork for a proposed bilateral trade agreement (BTA).
*   The discussions will focus on finalizing terms of reference (ToRs) across 19 key areas, including tariffs, non-tariff barriers, and customs facilitation.
*   Taiwan President William Lai Ching-te has reassured leaders of the aquaculture industry that the country’s ongoing tariff negotiations with the United States will not jeopardize its agricultural and fishery sectors.
*   While the White House recently paused a sweeping 32% import tariff on nations with trade surpluses — including Taiwan — a 10% tariff will still be enforced, with China being excluded from the exemption.
*   The U.S. administration announced on April 2, which seeks to impose “reciprocal” tariffs on countries with significant trade imbalances with the U.S.
*   Taiwan and the U.S. are expected to hold a second round of tariff negotiations soon, following preliminary discussions held on April 11.
*   The Trump administration’s tariffs — ranging from 10% on imports from most countries to as high as 145% on Chinese goods — are expected to make it even more expensive for new parents.
*   The Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association estimates that roughly 90% of baby care products and their components are produced in Asia, with the vast majority sourced from China.
*   Protesters returned to the streets to express frustration over Trump's policies, including the imposition and threats of tariffs.
*   Trump warned of retaliatory tariffs against countries imposing what he called “discriminatory” taxes on U.S. tech giants like Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft and Meta.
*   France collected €780 million ($887 million) last year under its tax, first introduced in 2019. Seven other nations have followed suit.
*   The EU is now weighing its own digital levy in response to Trump’s threats of 20% tariffs on European goods.
*   Britain may also revisit its £800 million digital tax amid hopes of securing a trade deal with Washington.
*   A broader effort by nearly 140 countries to tax multinational companies under a 2021 OECD agreement is also unraveling.
*   The deal includes two pillars: the first allows countries to tax companies where profits are made, while the second sets a global minimum tax rate of 15%.
*   The U.S. is home to nearly one-third of the world’s billionaires, more than any other nation.
*   A sharp rise in US trade protectionism is placing Arab economies under mounting pressure, endangering $22 billion worth of non-oil exports, according to a policy brief released by the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia (ESCWA).
*   Jordan emerges as the most vulnerable, with nearly a quarter of its total exports bound for the United States.
*   Bahrain is also flagged due to its heavy dependence on aluminum and chemical exports to the US market.
*   The United Arab Emirates could see disruptions to roughly 10 billion dollars in US-bound re-exports, a result of US tariffs on goods originally produced in third countries.
*   ESCWA projects that Egypt, Morocco, Jordan, and Tunisia will collectively face an additional 114 million dollars in sovereign interest payments in 2025.
*   Ford said Friday it has "adjusted" its exports to China.
*   Trump had roughly $125 million to about $443 million invested in bonds as of last year.
*   Volkswagen could relocate some production of its high-end Audi line to dodge US tariffs on automobiles.
*   Trump last month announced a 25-percent tariff on autos imported to the United States.
*   US Vice President JD Vance met with Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni in Rome on Friday for a second day of talks on tariffs.
*   The White House and Meloni's office on Friday issued a joint statement that said Trump would visit Italy “in the very near future.”
*   Indonesia said Friday it would boost oil and gas imports from the United States as part of a deal to ease stiff tariffs threatened by Washington, adding that talks would be completed within 60 days.
*   Indonesia will increase the purchase of energy from the US, including LPG, crude oil, and gasoline.
*   Indonesia also plans to keep buying agricultural products from the US, such as wheat, soybeans, and soybean milk.
*   The US has told the World Trade Organization (WTO) that its decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium imports was taken on national security grounds.
*   The US said the tariffs were imposed under Section 232 of US trade law.
*   The US has informed the global trade body WTO that the decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminium, was based on national security grounds and should not be considered as safeguard measures.
*   US lawmakers made a rare bipartisan visit to Taiwan this week, signaling enduring support for the island’s security and sovereignty.
*   President Trump earlier this month imposed sweeping tariffs, including a 32% hit on Taiwanese goods.
*   Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Thursday said that eliminating trade barriers within the country would deliver greater economic benefits than anything US President Donald Trump could undermine through his ongoing war.
*   Trump has raised, paused, and threatened tariffs.
*   Trump said the United States was in talks with China to make a deal on tariffs.
*   Trump said he could force out the independent head of the Federal Reserve, Jerome Powell.

content: 20/04/2025 .- Una encuesta a escala mundial de CGTN (China Global Televisión Network) en colaboración con la Universidad Renmin y el Instituto de Comunicación Internacional Nueva Era, reveló que el 78 ...
resumen:
Una encuesta a escala mundial de CGTN (China Global Televisión Network) en colaboración con la Universidad Renmin y el Instituto de Comunicación Internacional Nueva Era, reveló que el 78,6% de los europeos condena las intenciones de expansión territorial del presidente Donald Trump.

En otro sondeo la revista geopolítica Grand Continent, con sede en París, el 51% de los europeos califica al presidente Donald Trump de “enemigo”, mientras solo un 9% lo percibe como aliado “amistoso”, según la encuesta Eurobazuca, realizada el 20 de marzo de 2025.

El 63% de los encuestados opina que su presidencia compromete la seguridad del mundo, 43% lo acusa de tendencia autoritaria y 39% estima que su comportamiento es dictatorial.

El 55% teme que en lo próximos años se produzca un conflicto armado en territorio frente a un 40%.

América Latina se sumó a la tendencia anti Trump, proponiendo una respuesta única a su política.

Casi todos los países latinoamericanos y caribeños (CELAC), reunidos en una cumbre el pasado 9 de abril, plantearon afrontar las políticas migratorias y los aranceles impuestos por Donald Trump.

Brasil y México abogaron por una sola voz contra el “nuevo orden mundial”.

En su declaración de cierre, el bloque rechazó "la imposición de medidas coercitivas unilaterales, contrarias al Derecho Internacional, incluidas las restrictivas al comercio internacional".

Solo Argentina, Paraguay y Nicaragua dejaron de asistir por estar en desacuerdo con la resolución final.

El recién investido presidente de Estados Unidos ordenó habilitar la prisión de Guantánamo para trasladar a migrantes ilegales.

Desde el pasado mes de febrero, el Gobierno norteamericano empezó a trasladar migrantes en situación irregular a esa base militar situada en Cuba, como parte de sus medidas antimigratorias.

“Hoy, los primeros vuelos de Estados Unidos a la bahía de Guantánamo con migrantes ilegales están en curso”, confirmó la portavoz de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, al portal de noticias Fox Business.

Trump espera que la prisión caribeña reciba a 30.000 migrantes, incluyendo “criminales”.

title: Lessons from the fog of war - (Published 9 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: Comment: It would be helpful, as Winston Peters suggests, if we cease discussing Trump's trade war as if every snapshot of the field is a definitive view of the outcome, argues ...
resumen: The author, Hamish Price, writes that it would be helpful if discussions about Trump’s trade war ceased as if every snapshot of the field is a definitive view of the outcome, as Winston Peters suggests. The author writes that the only way to make genuine progress is to accept that the fog is there, make the best analysis and calculations you can, and take care to ensure you’re not shooting aimlessly into the void. The author mentions that Foreign Minister Winston Peters chided international media for using war-like language in describing the global tensions arising from US President Donald Trump’s tariff positioning. The author notes that a successful decoupling of the US from China in the global trading system may benefit New Zealand’s interests, could be disastrous, or may never happen. The author was a political adviser to Trade Minister Todd McClay in the Key-English government.

title: Markets are wrong about Trump's trade war and recession odds, says a longtime bull betting on a bounce-back - (Published 17 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: Wall Street's biggest bull changed his market outlook but is still optimistic. Here's why he says markets are wrong about President Trump's trade war.
resumen:
John Stoltzfus, the chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer, revised his S&P 500 price target from 7,100 to 5,950.
Stoltzfus still believes the US economy will avoid a downturn.
Stoltzfus entered the year with a Street-high S&P 500 target of 7,100, which implied the index was primed for another 20% gain.
US equities are flirting with bear market territory.
Stoltzfus' new year-end S&P 500 target of 5,950 means that they'd have to leap 12% from here to eke out a 1% gain.
Stoltzfus expects S&P 500 firms to generate a mid-single-digit gain in aggregate.
Stoltzfus thinks increased competition among places like restaurants and supermarkets will keep inflation in check.
Stoltzfus expects investors to carefully choose high-quality companies that are more likely to post resilient earnings.
Stoltzfus supports the Trump administration's plan to shake up the trade landscape.
Stoltzfus thinks the aim of Trump's protectionist trade policy is to shift the global economy away from China — preferably to the US, but to other countries as well.
Stoltzfus said the endpoint of this is just re-globalization with benefits for both developed and emerging markets outside of the US, to pick up some of the business that has been dedicated to China for so many years.
Stoltzfus noted that anti-globalism sentiment got exacerbated during the pandemic.
Stoltzfus said that the US should bring back industries that are critical to national defense and security, like semiconductors and healthcare products.
Stoltzfus said that if Trump can get the rest of the world to team up against China, his trade skirmish may succeed.
Stoltzfus is sticking with growth-heavy groups like technology and consumer discretionary, which happen to be the two worst-performing sectors so far this year.
His other outperform-rated sector is industrials.

title: Dos hermanos paisas triunfan en NY vendiendo mecato colombiano sin miedo a Trump y sus aranceles - (Published 12 hour(s), 15 minute(s) ago)
content: Luis y Rubén Velázquez, un par de campesinos paisas, como ellos gustan llamarse, hicieron en Nueva York, en Queens, un gran negocio de importación y distribución basado en los productos más queridos ...
resumen:
Luis y Rubén Velásquez, dos hermanos paisas, hicieron en Nueva York, en Queens, un negocio de importación y distribución de productos colombianos desde hace 36 años. Importan entre 300 o 400 productos colombianos, incluyendo rosquillas, papas fritas, besitos, platanitos, supercocos y molinos Corona, y otros del resto del mundo. Tienen aranceles del 10% impuestos por el presidente Donald Trump. Rubén, de 61 años, dirige el negocio.

Ahora están mandando siete contenedores con harina para buñuelos a Colombia para procesar en mezclas y vender en cajas de 340 gramos o en bultos, en su nueva bodega de producción, cerca de la cafetería y panadería Seba Seba. Empezaron con el bizcochuelo, que su abuela había pasado a sus hermanas Gilma Cecilia y Olga Lucía.

Dinas Corp, importadora y distribuidora, nació el 18 de julio de 1994.

La Niña de Pereira, empresa de Productora Nacional de Alimentos (Pronal), fue la primera en enviar contenedores a Nueva York con sus snacks.

Supercoco fue uno de los primeros productos enviados por Flipe Henao desde Manizales.

Los proveedores incluyen a Felipe Henao, gerente general de Supercoco, Juan Manuel Durán del Trapiche Lucerna, Julio Montoya, que les mandó los implementos de cocina, Fiorella Peros que les vende los condimentos El Rey, Gustar S.A. que fabrica el bocadillo de guayaba, y Luker para el chocolate, y la Federación de Cafeteros para el café.

Dinas importa 50 contenedores propios por año, abastece a 700 supermercados como CTown, Bravo, NSA, Associated Supermarkets, Key Food, y Trade Fair. Atienden 1.600 clientes directos y 40 subdistribuidores que los comercializan en 21 estados incluido Canadá. Venden USD 25 millones anuales.

La adaptación e innovación han sido clave. Rubén dice que la idea es estar siempre tres pasos más adelante, manteniendo siempre honestidad y el cumplimiento a clientes y proveedores. La administración de Nueva York les ha apoyado con incentivos como descuentos tributarios y acceso al crédito. Dinas incluye 60 empleos directos. Sus dos inmuebles, uno de ellos 10.000 metros cuadrados, fueron adquiridos mediante leasing.

Una línea de producción realiza las mezclas de harinas que se venden en cajas o en bultos.

Dinas también ofrece pupa de fruta congelada, palitos de queso y guayaba, pandebono, buñuelos, con su marca Castipan.

La mezcla para buñuelos es uno de los productos estrella.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Draft Executive Order Calls for Restructuring of State Department - (Published 17 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Supreme Court: Trump administration lawyers urged the Supreme Court in a court filing on Saturday to reject an emergency request to temporarily block deportations of Venezuelans under a rarely invoked ...
resumen: Senator Chris Van Hollen of Maryland accused the Trump administration of “outright defying” court orders to return Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, a wrongly deported Maryland man. Van Hollen met with Abrego Garcia in El Salvador last week and urged the administration to stop releasing unfavorable records about him. Van Hollen said the administration is “flouting the courts as we speak” and “facilitating his return means something more than doing nothing, and they are doing nothing.” A federal appeals court ordered the Trump administration to take a more active role in bringing back Abrego Garcia, after the Supreme Court ruled that the government should “facilitate” his return from El Salvador. The White House has publicized an allegation of domestic abuse from Abrego Garcia’s wife from 2021 and cited a police filing from a Tennessee trooper who stopped Abrego Garcia in 2022. Van Hollen said that Donald Trump is trying to change the subject and should “put up or shut up in court instead of litigating this through social media.” Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, brought Patty Morin, the mother of Rachel Morin, to a press briefing. A federal judge described the government’s claims accusing Abrego Garcia of being a member of the transnational street gang, MS-13, as “unsubstantiated.” Van Hollen expressed his sympathies toward Ms. Morin’s family while emphasizing the importance of ensuring due process for all of those in the United States. Van Hollen warned that the outcome of Abrego Garcia’s case could ultimately threaten the constitutional rights of U.S. citizens. Van Hollen also responded to some Democrats who were critical of his trip and the attention Mr. Abrego Garcia’s case has generated, including Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, who called the issue “a distraction.” Senator John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana, conceded that Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia “was not supposed to be sent” to El Salvador. Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. dissented in the Supreme Court’s decision to block the Trump administration from deporting a group of Venezuelan migrants, calling the court’s order “hastily and prematurely granted.” Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, said the Supreme Court should hold Trump administration officials in contempt if they continue to ignore a court order to facilitate Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia’s return from El Salvador. Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the Democratic leader, said that the energy of the Democratic Party right now is across the board and that this is a moment of right versus wrong. Senator Chris van Hollen said that President Trump “is trying to change the subject” by claiming Abrego Garcia is a member of the MS-13 gang and that Trump is “outright defying” the Supreme Court order to facilitate Abrego Garcia’s return. At the heart of two major legal cases challenging the Trump administration’s deportation actions are due process and habeas corpus. The Trump administration deported Venezuelan immigrants accused of being gang members, denying them a court hearing before they were expelled. The Supreme Court temporarily blocked their removal. The Trump administration deported a Maryland man to El Salvador in what the administration initially acknowledged was a mistake. A federal judge ordered the government to facilitate the return of the man, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, but it has not done so. Due process is the idea that people should have access to fair treatment before the law. Habeas corpus means that people who are in government custody have a right to challenge their status in a court hearing. Pope Francis met with JD Vance after criticizing the Trump administration’s immigration policies. Vice President JD Vance met with Pope Francis at the pontiff’s residence in Rome. The pope criticized the Trump administration’s deportation policies. A draft of a Trump administration executive order proposes a drastic restructuring of the State Department that includes eliminating almost all of its Africa operations and shutting down embassies and consulates across the continent. The draft also calls for cutting offices at State Department headquarters that address climate change and refugee issues, as well as democracy and human rights concerns. The purpose of the executive order is to impose “a disciplined reorganization” of the State Department and “streamline mission delivery” while cutting “waste, fraud and abuse.” The draft executive order calls for ending the foreign service exam for aspiring diplomats, and it lays out new hiring criteria that includes “alignment with the president’s foreign policy vision.” The draft says the department must greatly expand its use of artificial intelligence. The proposed reorganization would get rid of regional bureaus. One of the most drastic proposed changes is to eliminate the bureau of African affairs. The draft also said all “nonessential” embassies and consulates in sub-Saharan Africa would be closed by Oct. 1. The department would eliminate a bureau overseeing democracy and human rights issues; one that handles refugees and migration; and another that works with international organizations. The department would establish a new senior position, the under secretary for transnational threat elimination. The Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance would absorb the remnants of the U.S. Agency for International Development. The department would offer buyouts to foreign service and civil service officers until Sept. 30. The State Department has about 80,000 employees. The draft order also calls for narrowing Fulbright scholarships. The draft says the department will end its contract with Howard University. Trump administration lawyers urged the Supreme Court to reject an emergency request to temporarily block deportations of Venezuelans. Solicitor General D. John Sauer asked the justices to “dissolve” the administrative stay they had issued. Three top Pentagon officials who were accused of leaking unauthorized information issued a statement proclaiming their innocence. Dan Caldwell, Darin Selnick and Colin Carroll served as senior advisers to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Defense Secretary Stephen Feinberg before they were fired. Gov. Katie Hobbs of Arizona vetoed a bill that would have supported the Trump administration’s immigration enforcement efforts. The bill would have required state and local officials to cooperate with federal immigration officials. Thousands of protesters across the country once again took to the streets on Saturday to rally against President Trump and his policies. Demonstrations against the Trump administration were held in cities throughout the nation.

title: Trump(dis)order: Harsh tariffs rates based on wrong philosophy and wrong formula - (Published 7 hour(s), 25 minute(s) ago)
content: The harsh tariff rates imposed by US President Donald Trump on all exporters to USA have squarely hit the poor countries that export mainly items like apparels and rubber products. ..
resumen:
US President Donald Trump imposed harsh tariff rates on all exporters to the USA, particularly affecting poor countries exporting items like apparels and rubber products, mainly in Asia (Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Vietnam, and Cambodia). These high reciprocal tariffs were due to these countries running a trade surplus with the USA, though a 90-day pause has been implemented. Apparel buyers initially asked exporters to absorb the tariffs, but due to their unaffordable nature, orders were canceled or postponed. In Sri Lanka, both apparel and rubber product exports to the USA have suffered. Trump's tariff revisions have created market uncertainty. Large exporters to the USA like China, Canada, and the EU have retaliated with their own tariffs, leading to a never-ending tariff war.

The economic analyst Dhananath Fernando quoted American economist Otto T Mallery, who stated that if goods don't cross borders on missions of peace, soldiers will cross them on missions of war. Frédéric Bastiat also spoke of the benefits of free trade, implying that wars arise from barriers to free trade.

The author argues that Sri Lanka's focus on the 44% reciprocal tariff is too narrow, as Trump's policy will cause inflation in the USA, reducing the purchasing power of Americans, which will negatively impact Sri Lanka's exports. Retaliatory tariffs from major economic powers will also shrink their economies, further affecting Sri Lanka's exports.

The author has two issues with Trump's tariff revision plan: his interpretation of trade deficits and the formula used to calculate the amount allegedly "robbed" from US citizens. Trump claims trade surpluses indicate plundering of US citizens. The author argues that the US, as the unofficial central banker since 1971, has benefited from exchanging dollars for real goods. The formula used by Trump's advisors is also deemed irrelevant. The formula's co-author, Brent Neiman, disputes its context and application, stating it's not meant for mass-scale use on countries like Sri Lanka. Neiman confirmed that the actual price adjustment factor should have been 0.95, not 0.25, which would collapse the calculations made by Trump's advisors.

title: Opinion/Guest column: Fiscal signs point to US recession ahead - (Published 17 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: The tight monetary policy of the Federal Reserve and chaotic fiscal measures of Trump are not the right corrective measures and worsen the problems.
resumen:
In November, Hans Despain predicted on the Lee Elci radio show in New London, Connecticut, that the U.S. economy would experience a recession before the next presidential election in 2028.

International trade is sputtering due to trade disagreements globally, including those between the U.S. and China, and within the G7 nations, as well as tensions between the G7 and BRICS.

Total business debt stands at an all-time high of $21.6 trillion; $7.8 trillion is noncorporate debt. In 2021, the Federal Reserve estimated the percentage of U.S. firms unable to service their debt was 10%. New research shows that number may be closer to 15%.

Seventy-five percent of American industries have become more concentrated.

Since 1972 average hourly earnings have only increased 81 cents, taking inflation into account, over a 52-year period.

In 2022, it took on average 62.1 weeks of work per year for the average person to meet their cost-of-living expenses.

In 1985 it cost $17,586 for the necessities to “thrive,” and median annual income was $23,036. In 2022 the cost for necessities to “thrive” was $75,732, while median annual income was $63,388.

Household debt is at a record high of $18 trillion.

Auto loans are at an all-time high of $1.66 trillion. Student loans are at an all-time high of $1.61 trillion. Credit card debt is at an all-time high of $1.21 trillion.

The average credit card annual percentage rate in 2013 was 12.9%. By 2021 it was 16%. Today the average APR is 28.72%!

Mientras Trump impone aranceles a aliados y enemigos por igual, Milei se mueve en sentido contrario para deshacer una economía proteccionista y provocar un auge de las importaciones". Se nombró al exministro de Producción del gobierno de Mauricio Macri, Dante Sica, quien alertó: "Es como si estuviera aterrizando un avión en un día soleado y de repente se encontrara con una tormenta. El aterrizaje va a ser más duro". La nota hace referencia a las similitudes entre Trump y Milei, relacionadas a la agenda cultural: "En otros ámbitos, Milei ha emulado a Trump. Se ha hecho amigo de Elon Musk, ha dicho que sacaría a Argentina de la Organización Mundial de la Salud, ha hecho una malograda incursión en las monedas meme y ha restringido el tratamiento médico para los niños transgénero".

title: Una «bomba atómica» arancelaria - (Published Apr 20, 2025)
content: Usamos cookies en nuestro sitio web para brindarte la experiencia más relevante recordando tus preferencias y visitas repetidas. Al hacer clic en "Aceptar todo", acepta el uso de TODAS las cookies. Ta ...
resumen: Estados Unidos ha desatado una ola de choque en la economía mundial. El impacto de esa contraofensiva podría compararse con el «momento Nixon» de 1971, o con el «momento Reagan». Es imposible entender el «momento Trump» de la guerra arancelaria sin tener en cuenta la presión que ejercen más de cuarenta años de crónicos y gigantescos déficits comerciales y fiscales que son el talón de Aquiles de Estados Unidos. En 2024, el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos rondaba los 918.400 millones de dólares, mientras que el déficit fiscal alcanzaba los 1,8 billones de dólares. La deuda pública es de 36 billones de dólares y solamente el pago de intereses consumirá 1 billón de dólares. El Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) de Estados Unidos ascendía para esa fecha a 29,16 billones de dólares, todavía un 26,5 % del total mundial, pero en declive. El orden de Bretton Woods dio paso a la creación del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI). Entre 2001 y 2005, América Latina se vio convulsionada por una ola revolucionaria. La crisis mundial de 2007/08 fue una señal de que la financiación tenía límites inevitables. Estados Unidos emite la moneda de reserva mundial sin respaldo y sin reglas. La superioridad de Estados Unidos se impuso en el mundo porque ese privilegio fue decisivo para mantener una maquinaria bélica que hacía las veces de «paraguas atómico» que protegía a la Tríada. Desde la crisis de 2007/08 y la transición de Bush hijo a Barack Obama, hasta el primer mandato de Donald Trump, Estados Unidos ha practicado la estrategia del QE ( Quantitative Easing ). El choque arancelario de Donald Trump tiene como objetivo explícito internalizar las cadenas de producción. China está comenzando a desdolarizarse por el medio de la articulación de los BRICS. China mantiene ya un sistema de pagos en su propia moneda con Rusia. La sobrevaloración del dólar hizo que los costos de producción fueran muy elevados en Estados Unidos. Donald Trump tiene un plan y su estrategia es coherente con ese plan. Donald Trump ha roto con la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC), el Tratado de París y hasta con la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS), y desafía a la OTAN y las Naciones Unidas. También promueve abiertamente una ofensiva nacional-imperialista neocolonial. Irán y Venezuela se verán amenazados. México se salvará relativamente porque es una semicolonia con un estatus privilegiado. Estados Unidos apuesta por la recuperación de una mayor cohesión social interna en el país y por la industrialización de sectores estratégicos. El «momento Trump» será muy grave, quizás peor que las contraofensivas de Richard Nixon y Ronald Reagan, y ello por tres razones. La primera es que supone la existencia de un liderazgo neofascista en la Casa Blanca. La segunda es que nos enfrentamos a una crisis medioambiental inevitable, respecto de la cual Donald Trump es un negacionista. La tercera es que China no parece dispuesta a dar marcha atrás y ceder al chantaje. La ofensiva de Donald Trump se apoya internamente en una corriente supremacista blanca, misógina y homófoba. La respuesta de China será decisiva ante una carrera armamentista que ya se ha puesto en marcha en Europa contra Rusia, un incidente inminente con Irán y la perspectiva de una amenaza a la soberanía de Venezuela. El declive histórico de Estados Unidos ha engendrado un monstruo.

title: China Is Finding Ways to Replace American Farmers - (Published 17 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: China has long relied on the U.S. for soybeans. But with new steep tariffs, it is likely to look even more to Brazil and Argentina.
resumen:
The soybean, a legume about a centimeter in size, is eaten from the pod as edamame or processed into tofu, soy milk and other products. High in fat and protein, soybeans are what much of the world’s livestock eat.

The United States sells more soybeans to China, by value, than any other single product. Last year, that amounted to more than 27 million metric tons, worth $12.8 billion, or about 9 cents of every dollar of goods the United States sold to China.

With the enormous tariffs erected between the two countries, those sales are likely to suffer soon. This is bad news for the American farmers who grow soybeans and the Chinese chicken and hog farmers who buy them — and potentially very good news for Brazil.

More than half of U.S. soybean exports went to China last year, but the price just went up 135 percent under the tariffs China installed in response to President Trump’s 145 percent tax on Chinese imports.

American soybean farmers are worried about whether their biggest customer will keep buying.

The two South American countries produce 52 percent of the world’s soybeans, including 40 percent from Brazil alone, compared with 28 percent for the United States.

Neusa Lopes, a top executive at Girassol Agrícola, a major soybean producer in Brazil’s biggest soybean state, Mato Grosso, said that they could now sell a 130-pound sack of soybeans for about $21, up 10 percent from last month. Most of her crop goes to China, which is already by far Brazil’s largest soybean buyer.

Harvest season is ending in South America, and they have already sold nearly three-quarters of their stocks.

André Nassar, president of the Brazilian Association of Vegetable Oil Producers, which represents the nation’s largest soybean producers, said that those who haven’t yet sold are now capitalizing — or holding off and betting that the trade war will last, likely meaning even higher prices ahead.

Heather Feuerstein, who owns a farm near Grand Rapids, Mich., must begin planting her more than 200 acres soon. If she works hard, the weather cooperates and the bugs are managed, in late fall she will harvest 10,000 or more bushels, over 600,000 pounds of soybeans.

American soybean farmers say there isn’t much they can do besides plant and hope for the best.

From 2017, just before that trade war, to last year, China increased its annual imports of Brazilian soybeans 35 percent to 72.5 million metric tons while cutting imports of U.S. soybeans 14 percent to 27 million metric tons, according to data from the two countries.

China has poured money into warehouses, railroads, ports and other infrastructure in Brazil over the past decade to get more of the country’s soybeans onto Chinese ships.

This includes the opening this year of a giant terminal at Latin America’s largest port in Santos, Brazil. Cofco, a Chinese state food giant, is behind the nearly $500 million project, which will become its largest port outside China.

China’s vice minister of agriculture met with Brazil’s top agriculture officials. Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, announced last week that he would travel to Beijing to meet with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, next month.

The only thing that prevented ruin for American farmers during the last trade war was a $23 billion government bailout program. The Trump administration is again contemplating an agriculture bailout.

title: Más sanciones y menos aliados: el arranque del nuevo gobierno de Maduro en cifras - (Published 11 hour(s), 14 minute(s) ago)
content: El gobierno venezolano enfrenta sanciones renovadas, el retorno de migrantes y una reforma constitucional en marcha, mientras países como Perú mantienen su rechazo a la legitimidad del mandato.
resumen:
Nicolás Maduro llegó a los primeros 100 días de su tercer mandato presidencial en Venezuela. El período ha estado acompañado de observaciones nacionales e internacionales sobre el proceso electoral, medidas de política exterior y cambios en el panorama económico y social del país.

Maduro fue proclamado vencedor por el Consejo Nacional Electoral (CNE). Los resultados detallados del proceso no han sido publicados. El Centro Carter concluyó en febrero que las elecciones no pueden ser consideradas democráticas.

La Plataforma Unitaria Democrática (PUD) reiteró que el ganador fue Edmundo González Urrutia y calificó la proclamación de Maduro como una ruptura del orden constitucional.

Entre los que reconocen a Maduro se encuentran Rusia, China, Irán, Turquía, Bielorrusia, Cuba, Nicaragua y Bolivia. Estados Unidos, Canadá, Argentina, Colombia, Brasil, Perú, Reino Unido, Alemania, Japón y otros países han cuestionado su legitimidad.

Con el retorno de Donald Trump a la presidencia de Estados Unidos, se intensificaron las sanciones económicas contra Venezuela. Se eliminaron licencias para operar con el sector petrolero venezolano y se impusieron aranceles del 25 % a los compradores de crudo y del 15 % a otros productos venezolanos.

La administración venezolana respondió con la declaratoria de un estado de emergencia económica y la emisión de una alerta de viaje advirtiendo sobre supuestos riesgos para ciudadanos en Estados Unidos.

Desde febrero, 2.559 ciudadanos venezolanos han retornado al país, la mayoría desde Estados Unidos. Estos vuelos de repatriación, trece en total, fueron posibles gracias a un acuerdo alcanzado durante una visita a Caracas de Richard Grenell, representante especial de la Casa Blanca.

El gobierno venezolano criticó las recientes deportaciones realizadas por EE.UU., entre ellas, el envío de más de 200 personas a El Salvador por presunta vinculación con el grupo criminal Tren de Aragua.

Maduro ha anunciado que durante el año se celebrarán al menos diez procesos electorales, entre ellos las elecciones regionales y parlamentarias programadas para el 25 de mayo.

Se prepara un proyecto de reforma constitucional encabezado por una comisión liderada por el fiscal general Tarek William Saab. La iniciativa deberá ser presentada en mayo.

Se elegirá por primera vez un gobernador para la Guayana Esequiba, un territorio de aproximadamente 160,000 km² que está en disputa con Guyana. El gobierno guyanés solicitó a la Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ) medidas para evitar actos que considere violatorios de su soberanía.

El tipo de cambio oficial del dólar en Venezuela ha subido de 53,87 a 80,95 bolívares, lo que representa un incremento del 50,26 %, mientras que la cotización en el mercado paralelo superó los 100 bolívares.

El Observatorio Venezolano de Finanzas (OVF) reportó una inflación acumulada del 36,1 % durante el primer trimestre.

Gremios sindicales han solicitado un ajuste del salario mínimo, actualmente equivalente a 1,60 dólares mensuales sin contar bonos, frente a un costo estimado de 100 dólares mensuales para cubrir necesidades básicas de alimentación.
