title: It’s Gotten Riskier to Be a Long-Term Investor - (Published 22 hour(s), 51 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump’s policies have shaken the markets. Protect yourself first, and, only then, take advantage of investment bargains, our columnist says.
resumen: Uncertainty has defined financial markets this year. Tariffs are the main financial issue. President Trump has sometimes backpedaled when the markets have plunged. He and other members of his administration have made it clear that higher tariffs of some sort are here, even though they are unpopular and most economists say they are a mistake. The risk of higher inflation and slower economic growth, along with strained relations with China and with many erstwhile allies, now appears to be a fact of life. Mr. Trump says he is at heart “a tariff man” and wants to change the world. Disruption is here to stay. This is causing problems for investors. Bonds are a case in point. The Treasury market has gotten considerable attention lately because, in response to the tariff announcements, yields rocketed and prices sank in a manner that has, in the past, been associated with full-blown financial crises. The chances of further eruptions are high. They may even be set off by other parts of the Trump policy tool kit — say, the president’s goal of extending tax cuts that expire this year and adding new ones, enormously expanding the federal budget deficit and the Treasuries needed to finance it. Another administration policy goal may be causing problems for bonds: weakening the value of the dollar to make U.S. exports more competitive and imports more expensive. Stephen Miran, now the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, made unorthodox proposals for accomplishing this feat while, at the same time, maintaining the dollar’s role as the center of world finance. Global investors are already having second thoughts about the wisdom of holding U.S. dollars and Treasuries, and the dollar’s value has been falling. Nellie Liang, former under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, put it in a piece for the Brookings Institution, some investors speculate that the cause of the furor in Treasuries comes from “increasing doubts about Treasury securities as the pre-eminent global safe-haven asset, consistent with the decline in the dollar.” “A re-pricing of Treasury debt for this reason would be very consequential," she added, “forcing the U.S. government to pay more to borrow to finance deficits and raising the costs of borrowing for businesses and households.” It will take time to “disentangle” the causes and the gravity of the problem, she said. It’s harder to be a long-term investor. Many people can ignore these shifts and hang on to their government bonds and bond funds. Those looking to lock in high yields may find occasional bargains, when Treasury yields jump close to 5 percent, as they did earlier this month. Everyone — even if not an investor — is being exposed to innumerable risks that may not be entirely appreciated. The standard advice in a crisis is to avoid doing anything hasty. Evaluate your own strategy. If it’s sound, there may be no need to make any changes. Figure out how much money you’re going to need fairly soon because both the stock and bond markets have become much more volatile. When I sense a crisis may be coming, I bulk up my cash holdings in safe interest-bearing accounts so I won’t need to dip into core investments in a downturn. Money market funds, high-yield savings accounts and short-duration certificates of deposit are good for this purpose. If you are retired and living off your investments or planning to send a child to college, safety may be your predominant concern. In that case, consider whether you need more liquid assets than you did in quieter periods for the markets. Well-stocked interest-bearing accounts can be a balm in times of trouble. Broadly diversified portfolios holding stocks and bonds from around the world have been outperforming the U.S. stock market this year. Such portfolios have had low, single-digit gains or losses — much better than the nearly 10 percent decline, including dividends, of the S&P 500 stock index. Betting exclusively on any particular market is risky. Over the last 20 years, the U.S. stock market has outperformed most others. Diversifying among many markets, using low-cost index funds, makes sense. My own portfolio resembles the Vanguard Target Retirement 2030 Fund, which is geared toward people who might want to retire in five years. Its holdings are about 60 percent stock and 40 percent bonds, with roughly two-thirds focused on U.S. markets and one-third on international ones. It’s down 2.5 percent this year. Traditionally, you add bonds to your portfolio for greater safety and add stocks for long-term growth. Younger people may even want to put almost all of their long-term savings in stocks, though there is, of course, a risk of losses, now or in the future. From 1926 through 2023, large U.S. stocks returned 10.3 percent annualized, while U.S. government bonds returned 5.1 percent, including dividends. Mr. Trump is deliberately breaking with past U.S. policies in many ways, adding stress to financial markets. The stock market has already had abrupt reactions to tariff announcements, and I expect more to come. High tariffs are likely to dent corporate earnings. And they have increased the chance of a recession. Jumping into the stock market when it falls — “buying the dips” — may not look like a brilliant approach if the market falls further and you were counting on a quick profit. The bond market has been volatile, too. Buying bonds after yields have risen (and prices, which move in the opposite direction, have dropped) could also backfire if there’s more distress in the bond market and yields keep rising. Long-term investors — with a horizon of at least a decade and preferably longer — can practice what’s known as dollar-cost averaging by investing steadily. The average cost of your investments will be lower if you keep buying when the market is down. The administration’s policies make it less certain that Treasuries will serve as an effective shield in a possible stock market downturn. One answer is holding shorter-duration Treasuries. They won’t move much in price if the market shifts and are a safe short-term bet. They won’t rise in value in recessions as much as longer-term bonds will, and they won’t offset stock portfolio losses, either.

title: The Trump administration says Europe is taking advantage of the US. That’s not exactly true - (Published 21 hour(s), 52 minute(s) ago)
content: Maintaining a good relationship between the United States and Europe has long been seen as a no-brainer by leaders on both side of the Atlantic. After all, it’s this friendship that has led to decades ...
resumen:
The Trump administration believes Europe is taking advantage of the US.

Donald Trump and his aides have expressed disdain for Europe, believing the continent takes advantage of the US regarding security and trade. They claim the US has subsidized Europe's defense spending while facing tariffs and trade barriers.

Majda Ruge, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, said Trump's foreign policy is an extension of the culture wars against liberalism, with Europe seen as a bastion of it. Trump's "Make America Great Again" movement is inspired by disappointment with globalization, grievances against globalization, elites, international organizations, and progressive liberal policies.

Vice President JD Vance has shown contempt for Europe, berating them over free speech and migration at the Munich Security Conference. He suggested the biggest threat to European security was "the retreat of Europe from some of its most fundamental values."

In a group chat, Vance suggested calling off a US attack on the Houthi rebels in Yemen because it would benefit European economies more than America's. Trump believes European countries have underspent on defense because they knew the US would bail them out. He has threatened to take the US out of NATO and questioned Article 5 of the treaty.

In 2024, only eight out of NATO's 32 members didn't meet the agreed-upon 2% of their GDP on defense.

Ruge said the US has rarely done anything in foreign policy that hasn't benefited or aligned with US national interests.

Sudha David-Wilp, vice president of external relations and senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund of the United States, warned that pulling away from the alliance could cost the US. The US has benefited from the network created in the last 70 years.

Trump and those close to him have pushed for the US to pull back from its role as the world's policeman.

Vance suggested that if Europe was "a little more willing to stand up" to the US, it "could have saved the entire world from the strategic disaster that was the American-led invasion of Iraq."

The US has a vast network of military bases across Europe, with some 80,000 service members deployed there.

According to research by the Atlantic Council, it would cost the US taxpayer nearly $70 million more per year to rotate military forces in and out of Europe rather than have them based in Germany and Poland.

The US is pouring money into American defense contractors.

Of the more than $175 billion in aid the US Congress has appropriated to Ukraine since the start of the full-scale invasion, more than $120 billion has been spent directly with US companies or on US Forces.

European countries have provided even more aid to Ukraine than the US.

Trump has made his personal contempt for the European Union clear on multiple occasions. He claimed the EU was "formed to screw the United States."

The US and the EU have the largest trading relationship in the world, having traded $1.4 trillion worth of goods and services in 2023. The US ran a trade deficit with the EU in goods but had a surplus in services.

The two sides have been balancing on the edge of a trade war after Trump unveiled 25% tariffs on European steel, aluminum and car exports, and 20% "reciprocal" tariffs on all other goods.

title: La pobreza en América Latina - (Published 7 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: Existen varias causas que determinan la pobreza en una sociedad. Veamos las principales que afectan a Latinoamérica. Principales causas de la pobreza en América Latina 1. Las causas institucionales.
resumen:
La pobreza se refiere a la carencia, escasez o falta de los bienes elementales (alimentos, vivienda, educación o asistencia sanitaria y agua potable), así como de los medios para obtenerlo.

Principales causas de la pobreza en América Latina:
1. Las causas institucionales.
2. La desigual concentración de los ingresos.
3. La degradación ambiental.
4. El funcionamiento irregular de los mercados internacionales.
5. La distorsión de los precios de productos campesinos.
6. Una reforma agraria parcialmente encarada.
7. El fenómeno de la dependencia de los países industrializados.
8. La carga extrema de la deuda interna y sus intereses.

Dentro de las causas institucionales encontramos la corrupción en la gestión pública con absoluta impunidad, la baja inversión en maquinarias, equipos y capital humano, la falta de políticas económicas y sociales adecuadas, escaso apoyo a las pequeñas y medianas empresas, etc.

La pobreza extrema absoluta es aquella situación en que todos los ingresos no alcanzan para satisfacer las necesidades nutricionales.

Aspectos medibles de la pobreza:
- La cantidad de alimentos.
- La variedad de alimentos.
- El valor calórico de los alimentos.
- El mobiliario y los servicios básicos de la vivienda.
- El empleo permanente como fuente de ingreso.
- La seguridad social.

Según datos del BID, en los últimos 20 años América Latina aumentó el número de pobres en la población total. El porcentaje de pobreza es mayor en el área rural que en el área urbana, siendo algunas de las causas la vulnerabilidad del sistema productivo que depende de dos o tres rubros agrícolas de exportación, los vaivenes de los precios internacionales, los cambios climáticos y la migración hacia las ciudades en busca de mejores oportunidades.

La calidad de vida tiene relación con la renta per cápita, el producto interno bruto, el promedio de vida, el porcentaje de graduados universitarios, el grado de calorías de su alimentación, la infraestructura sanitaria y educativa, el porcentaje de alfabetización, el alcance de servicios básicos como la luz, el agua y los desagües cloacales, número de periódicos vendidos, libros nacionales editados, horas destinadas al trabajo y al ocio, etc.

La desigualdad de los ingresos es un indicador de carácter económico. La diferencia entre los países es de uno a diez.

Consecuencias del desigual ingreso:
- Mortalidad infantil.
- Trabajo de los niños.
- Deserción escolar.
- Trabajo informal.
- Desnutrición.
- Hacinamiento.
- Falta de participación sociopolítica.
- Baja esperanza de vida. Analfabetismo.
- Subempleo.

Algunos aspectos de la cooperación de los países latinoamericanos podrían ser:
- Levantar las barreras proteccionistas.
- Bajar las tasas de interés.
- Realizar introducción de capitales a través de inversiones directas.
- Cooperar en programas educativos con el ofrecimiento de becas y capacitaciones.

La acelerada e indiscriminada deforestación es un factor de empobrecimiento de la región que deja graves secuelas, como:
- La sequía como problema ambiental.
- Aumento de la desertización del suelo.
- La desaparición de la fauna y la flora.
- La expansión de los cultivos comerciales.

Fuente: RIVAROLA PAOLI, Juan Bautista y VALLEJO FERRARI, Lía (2005). Economía y Gestión (Segundo Curso de la Educación Media), Ed. Aries, Asunción, págs. 110-115.

title: Nvidia’s 2025 has been anything but easy. And it’s going to get tougher. - (Published 11 hour(s), 35 minute(s) ago)
content: It’s been a difficult 2025 for Nvidia so far. The company, which had a blockbuster 2024, is beset by challenges that have sent its stock price plummeting. Its most recent setbac ...
resumen: Nvidia (NVDA) has faced challenges in 2025, leading to a decline in its stock price. The Trump administration will require the company to obtain export licenses to sell its H20 chips to customers in China, effectively banning sales to the country. Nvidia will book a $5.5 billion charge in the first quarter related to H20 products and purchase commitments. President Trump is expected to enact tariffs on semiconductors imported from overseas, including devices like laptops and desktops, impacting Nvidia’s consumer and enterprise gaming and graphics chip sales. AI diffusion export controls will go into effect in May, requiring certain countries to acquire special licenses to access a limited number of AI chips. Nvidia's shares were down 24% year to date as of late Thursday, and more than 6% over the last five days alone. Its Blackwell chips continue to sell well. The H20 restrictions could result in a 5% to 8% cut to Nvidia’s fiscal 2026 sales and a 6% to 10% impact on its earnings per share, according to BofA’s Vivek Arya. John Vinh of KeyBanc estimated that H20 sales would account for roughly $12 billion in revenue for Nvidia through its fiscal Q3. China is Nvidia’s fourth-largest market, accounting for $17.1 billion in sales in the company’s fiscal 2025. The US is its largest market at $61.2 billion, followed by Singapore ($23.6 billion) and Taiwan ($20.5 billion). Nvidia committed to spend $500 billion on AI infrastructure in the US over the next four years. The US's AI diffusion rules, put in place by the Biden administration, set up a three-tier system for access to AI chips, including China being fully restricted. Republican Senators sent a letter to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick asking him to rescind the AI diffusion order before it goes into effect May 15. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) insulates Nvidia servers built in Mexico from additional tariffs.

title: Aranceles, saqueo y una nueva oportunidad: Trump reactiva el ALCA versión 2.0 - (Published 17 hour(s), 59 minute(s) ago)
content: El nuevo paquete de aranceles que el presidente de EE.UU, impuso sobre las exportaciones agrícolas y otros productos de América Latina, tiene un claro mensaje: no hay amigos, hay ...
resumen: El nuevo paquete de aranceles que el presidente de EE.UU, impuso sobre las exportaciones agrícolas y otros productos de América Latina, tiene un claro mensaje: no hay amigos, hay intereses. La medida, que grava con un 10% a la mayoría de los países latinoamericanos y castiga particularmente a Venezuela y Nicaragua con un 15% y 18% respectivamente, representa mucho más que un movimiento proteccionista: es una advertencia. El capitalismo estadounidense, con su expresión política más brutal en Donald Trump, vuelve a golpear sobre la producción, los mercados y la soberanía de los países de Latinoamérica y El Caribe. Solo México y Canadá quedaron fuera del golpe, al amparo del T-MEC. Esto impacta en un mercado entre EEUU y Latinoamérica y El Caribe de alrededor de 100 mil millones de dólares al año. La exportación de productos es la fuente de ingreso de divisas, necesarias para el desarrollo de las economías locales, ya sea por la necesidad de compra de insumos y tecnología, como por el pago de deuda. El uso de la deuda como herramienta de opresión ha sido desde el nacimiento del capitalismo la alternativa al sometimiento bélico. Los países tienen una enorme necesidad de dólares, lo que hace que la medida de Donald Trump sea una extorsión y un sometimiento total de los pueblos de América Latina. Lo que se exporta en materia agroindustrial en América Latina es TRABAJO, TIERRA, AGUA, etc. El 23 de junio de 2023, desde el CEA, se escribió una nota para Nodal, titulada: ¿Hay un Nuevo ALCA en las Américas? En el marco de una Nueva Fase del sistema capitalista, nos encontramos en un escenario que recuerda demasiado al del ALCA, el Área de Libre Comercio de las Américas. El capitalismo necesita de América Latina para sostenerse, principalmente el Agua dulce para las megaciudades, el Litio para las baterías, el petróleo, el gas y los Combustibles para las industrias, y los Alimentos para sostener la fuerza de trabajo. Este nuevo ALCA, asedia a América Latina, ya que no es solo víctima, es un territorio codiciado por su abundancia estratégica. Es una forma de guerra económica, que impone castigos selectivos a los países más “rebeldes” –como Nicaragua y Venezuela– al tiempo que protege a los aliados funcionales del orden capitalista imperante. Los países latinoamericanos podrían aprovechar la coyuntura para retomar el camino de la integración regional. La CELAC, el ALBA, la UNASUR, pueden ser espacios de reactivación.

title: Whoever wins the federal election on May 3 will face a fork in the road for Australia's future - (Published 12 hour(s), 52 minute(s) ago)
content: The winner at the polls on May 3 will face not just a game of global economic and geo-strategic chess, but possibly an epoch-defining choice for the country.
resumen:
The winner of the federal election on May 3 will face a fork in the road for Australia's future. The "debate" veers between a schoolyard discussion about who can be besties with the loudmouth bully, and a slightly uneasy, and not quite addressed noting of the fact that, er, the world trade system and geopolitics are in a state of complete upheaval. The way our relationships with the United States and China might play out amid this upheaval tends to be seen in bilateral terms. Whoever wins on May 3 will face not just a multi-dimensional game of global economic and geo-strategic chess, but possibly an epoch-defining choice for the country.

Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni met with President Trump at the White House this week. Trump declared that there would "100 per cent" be a trade deal with the European Union. For her part, she said: "the goal for me is to make the West great again — and I think together we can do it". There is now something of a battle going on between the world's biggest economies for the heart and trade of the EU. China has been moving to rewire its global trade connections in the wake of the Trump tariffs and has been escalating its trade talks with the European market in recent weeks. The EU has shifted its language away from talk about its strategic vulnerability to China to a discussion about mutually beneficial ties. This is all being done in a world where the possibility of two major trading blocs emerging is now being discussed: a trading bloc with the United States at its centre, and one with China at its centre.

Analysts say that everything the Trump administration is doing now is aimed at isolating China economically. The EU — which collectively is one of the world's biggest trading blocs — is obviously the biggest prize to gain for either the US or China in creating a powerful trade bloc.

Financial Times columnist Rana Foroohar wrote recently:"The U.S doesn't even want to count unequivocally on allies that have significant trade relationships with China, as Europe does (China is the EU's largest import partner, and trade dependency between the two regions has increased in recent years), because the administration doesn't believe it will be able to trust them, given their economic dependence on Beijing."

Diplomats in Canberra ask these days where Australia would sit if we ended up in a world of two competing trade blocs: with the US or China? Strategic analyst Hugh White has argued for years that Australia would likely face a choice between its key strategic partner, the United States, and its major trading partner, China. The complex wheels of the haphazard Trump administration "strategy" on tariffs and rebalancing the world order means that this prospect of two new global trading blocs emerging now underpins the possibility of us having to make an economic choice between the US and China which obviously has strategic consequences.

It's become known as the "Mar-a-Lago' Accord": an ambition to build up the US manufacturing sector by a combination of tariffs and a much weaker US dollar. The chair of Trump's Council of Economic Advisers, Stephen Miran, wrote a paper late last year — A User's Guide to Restructuring the Global Trading System. — which canvassed these issues. The proposed solution is to force the rest of the world to appreciate their currencies to improve US export competitiveness, and also converting their significant US debt into 100 year bonds.

A special pre-election Lowy Institute Poll released this week reported a new 20-year low in the level of trust expressed by Australians towards the United States, with just 36 per cent of Australians expressing any level of trust in the US to act responsibly. Eighty per cent of Australians disapproved of Donald Trump's use of tariffs to pressure other countries to comply with his administration's objectives. However, the vast majority of Australians — 80 per cent — continued to say the US alliance is "very" or "fairly" important for Australia's security, steady on last year.

title: Trump’s Trade War Puts Bromance With Xi Beyond Reach - (Published 15 hour(s), 0 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump says he wants Xi Jinping, China’s leader, to call him to talk tariffs. Mr. Xi is ghosting Mr. Trump, and markets are plummeting.
resumen:
The global economy hinges on a phone call that hasn’t even been scheduled.

As the Trump administration escalates its trade war, and as China retaliates, the American president and his aides say they are expecting Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, to call.

Mr. Trump said at a cabinet meeting last week: “I have great respect for President Xi. He’s been a friend of mine for a long period of time, and I think that we’ll end up working out something that’s very good for both countries.”

Mr. Xi is ghosting Mr. Trump. He has flown instead to Southeast Asia this week to meet with leaders there to try to persuade them to stand with China in the trade war.

A Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman earlier this month posted a video of Mao Zedong speaking in 1953, during the Korean War, in which China fought the United States: “No matter how long this war is going to last, we will never yield. We’ll fight until we completely triumph.”

A bromance with Mr. Xi that Mr. Trump has desired for years is slipping out of his reach.

With that goes a quick resolution to Mr. Trump’s trade war, tipping the American economy closer to a recession and vaporizing trillions of dollars from the U.S. stock market since he took office on Jan. 20. The trade conflict also threatens to inflame military and diplomatic tensions between the two superpowers.

Mr. Trump imposed a 125 percent tariff on Chinese goods.

With Mr. Xi, Mr. Trump’s standard playbook of escalating conflict between two nations to get to a leader-to-leader summit has not worked so far.

Mr. Trump asserts that China has cheated on trade with the United States for decades, but that the world’s two most powerful men can reset relations once they talk on the phone and meet.

Mr. Trump is especially drawn to the idea of becoming partners with Mr. Xi and other autocrats.

In Mr. Xi, he has encountered an authoritarian leader who steered his nation in a much more nationalistic direction years before Mr. Trump ever took office, and who sees an advantage in fueling those sentiments among Chinese citizens, whether it is on issues of international trade or Taiwan or U.S.-China relations.

Mr. Xi, the son of Communist Party royalty, had stressed the need to hit back against what he called America’s growing efforts to undermine party rule. He has even stoked anti-American nationalism by using propaganda around the Korean War.

Ryan Hass, a Brookings Institution scholar who was China director on the National Security Council in the Obama administration, said: “Xi has devoted a large part of his presidency to building an image as a defender of national honor and a deliverer of China’s national rise. He will go to great lengths to avoid any appearance of being bullied into negotiating with Trump on America’s terms.”

Mr. Hass added: “The Trump administration has appeared confounded by Beijing’s entirely anticipable reaction to Trump’s tariff escalation. China’s leaders do not view tit-for-tat tariffs as an isolated trade issue that lends itself to a negotiated resolution.”

Mr. Xi would be reluctant to speak with Mr. Trump unless teams from the two nations first laid a foundation for top-level discussions.

Yun Sun, a China analyst at the Stimson Center, said: “Xi fears being treated like Zelensky, plus he doesn’t know what good will come out for him from a call. The mess about the call is a total contest of egos.”

Chinese officials prefer sending envoys to Washington to try to persuade Mr. Trump’s aides to get the president to budge on the tariffs.

Cui Tiankai, the former ambassador to the United States, tried to do that earlier this month.

Ms. Sun said: “My understanding is that Cui didn’t get through to the administration.”

The Chinese government announced a new trade envoy on Wednesday: Li Chenggang, a former representative to the World Trade Organization and Commerce Ministry official, who took part in trade talks during the first Trump administration.

One of the loudest voices on trade, Peter Navarro, a White House adviser who shaped China policy in the first Trump administration, is content with a freeze in talks between the two countries. Mr. Navarro, co-author of a book called “Death by China,” has long advocated decoupling the world’s two largest economies. (He served a four-month prison sentence last year for defying a congressional subpoena in a House investigation of Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election.)

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, a former hedge fund manager who is sensitive to market turmoil, has said that the two sides should be talking, and that he has “a lot of confidence” in the relationship between Mr. Trump and Mr. Xi.

Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, suggested the same in an interview with The Financial Times this week.

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick insists that the only talk Mr. Trump wants for now is a one-on-one chat with Mr. Xi.

Mr. Lutnick told reporters: “If we get a contact, we will just pass it to the president, and this is really about him. He has said publicly that maybe they don’t really know the best way to go through, but the answer really is, it’s a phone call between the two leaders of these giant countries that they can work it out together.”

In his first administration, Mr. Trump tried this approach with Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea. Initially, Mr. Trump escalated tensions, even threatening military action against North Korea with “fire and fury.” Then the leaders traded what Mr. Trump called “beautiful letters” before eventually meeting at a summit in Singapore in 2018 to discuss a potential halt to Mr. Kim’s nuclear weapons program.

They met again in Hanoi the next year, but failed to reach a deal. Mr. Kim has since continued to build up his nuclear stockpile.

Mr. Trump talks about building a partnership with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and meeting with the Russian leader, even as Mr. Putin rejects a full cease-fire deal that Mr. Trump has proposed to bring a 30-day halt to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

In late January, just three days before his inauguration, Mr. Trump called Mr. Xi, who congratulated him on his return to power. Mr. Xi’s vice president attended the inauguration.

Mr. Hass said he thought the only way such a meeting could happen was “if it is hosted by a third party with a vested interest in encouraging both leaders to find a face-saving way to climb down from their current confrontation.”

A European nation could play that mediator role. So could Singapore or Vietnam, which hosted the talks between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim and happen to be strong advocates of free trade. Mr. Xi discussed trade with the leader of Vietnam during his visit this week.

title: In China’s ‘Christmas Town,’ Trump’s tariffs are dimming the lights - (Published 21 hour(s), 52 minute(s) ago)
content: Your Christmas decorations probably come from this one Chinese city. But anxiety is high, with vendors on the front lines of the US-China trade war.
resumen: In Yiwu, China, nicknamed “Christmas Town,” which supplies nearly 90% of all decorative Christmas goods used in the United States, vendors are grappling with triple-digit tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. America’s overall tariffs on China now exceed 145%, the highest trade penalties imposed by the US in nearly a century. For many vendors, the measures have already cost them customers, slashed their profits and forced them to pivot to other markets. Ran Hongyan, 43, who has been selling Christmas decorations for 15 years, said that after the tariffs hit, she tried offering her American customers a discount to save the relationship, but it didn’t work. Eight out of ten canceled their contracts this year, representing a loss of more than $135,000. The second-biggest exporter of Christmas decorations to the US is Cambodia, where factory wages are even lower than China, but Trump also imposed 49% tariffs on the small Southeast Asian nation, before the recent 90-day pause. Last year, Yiwu sent $81 billion of goods overseas, of which about $11.5 billion went to the US, according to local customs data. Li Xinyao has been working at her family’s imitation flower business at Yiwu market since it was established in 1993. Nie Ziqin, who sells Halloween decorations, said that half of her customers for Halloween decorations were American before the tariffs hit. Last week Beijing raised tariffs on US goods to 125%.

title: Temu y Shein subirán sus precios en Estados Unidos debido a aranceles de Trump - (Published 10 hour(s), 41 minute(s) ago)
content: Ambas plataformas subirán sus precios en Estados Unidos desde el 25 de abril. Los aranceles del 145 % y el fin de exenciones fiscales afectan su modelo de ...
resumen:
Temu y Shein subirán sus precios en Estados Unidos a partir del 25 de abril.
La decisión responde a las nuevas medidas arancelarias impuestas por el presidente Donald Trump a los productos fabricados en China.
El nuevo paquete incluye un arancel del 145 % sobre gran parte de las importaciones chinas, así como la eliminación de la exención fiscal que aplicaba a productos de menos de 800 dólares.
Ambas compañías aprovecharon esa exención —conocida como “disposición de minimis”— para enviar millones de paquetes sin pagar aranceles.
Esa ventaja desaparecerá el 2 de mayo.
Temu aseguró que se ha reabastecido con anticipación y que hará “todo lo posible por mantener los precios bajos”.
También está invirtiendo en almacenes dentro de Estados Unidos.
Shein ha acelerado la expansión de centros de distribución en suelo estadounidense.
Ambas empresas figuran entre las que más invirtieron en publicidad digital el año pasado.
Tras el anuncio de las nuevas tarifas, han reducido su presencia publicitaria en plataformas como Facebook, Instagram, TikTok y X, según datos de la firma Sensor Tower.
Pekín impuso nuevos aranceles a productos estadounidenses de hasta un 125 %.
China ordenó a sus aerolíneas no aceptar más entregas de aviones Boeing.
Los consumidores en Estados Unidos comenzarán a notar los incrementos en los próximos días.
Ambas compañías recomendaron aprovechar los precios actuales antes del 25 de abril.

title: Por qué las amenazas de Trump al Canal de Panamá no cuadran - (Published 16 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: La retórica agresiva de la administración Trump sobre la influencia china en Panamá es una excusa para presionar al país a ceder un mayor control sobre el Canal de Panamá, siendo el verdadero objetivo ...
resumen:
La retórica agresiva de la administración Trump sobre la influencia china en Panamá es una excusa para presionar al país a ceder un mayor control sobre el Canal de Panamá, siendo el verdadero objetivo de Washington reafirmar el dominio estadounidense a expensas de la autonomía de Panamá y sus asociaciones internacionales.

El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, parece dar por sentado que Panamá es el dueño y administrador del Canal de Panamá. La última excusa para las tácticas de presión de Washington es la supuesta "influencia china", que Estados Unidos sigue reivindicando sin pruebas convincentes.

El secretario de Defensa, Pete Hegseth, declaró que Estados Unidos no permitirá que la China comunista ni ningún otro país amenace el funcionamiento o la integridad del canal.

La retórica en torno a la supuesta "influencia china" en el Canal carece de pruebas tangibles. La administración Trump ha optado por amplificar estas amenazas para ganarse la confianza de la Ciudad de Panamá.

En enero de 2025, Trump afirmó que el Canal de Panamá había sido entregado "insensatamente" al país.

Estados Unidos amenaza abiertamente con el uso de "fuerza militar letal" para asegurar el acceso al Canal a todos los países del mundo.

La administración Trump es el mayor impedimento para el comercio libre y sin restricciones en todo el mundo.

Las reiteradas amenazas de Trump han obligado a Panamá a aumentar la presión sobre la empresa matriz de Panama Ports para que abandone el país. La presión estadounidense también contribuyó a socavar los lazos de independencia de Panamá con China.

Washington intensificó la presión sobre Panamá para que pusiera fin a su participación en la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI) de China.

Las empresas chinas de gestión portuaria que operan en Panamá han operado en el país durante muchas décadas y no constituyen una amenaza para el Canal. Las instalaciones asociadas también son administradas por empresas fuera de China.

Washington cuestiona deliberadamente su control consolidado del Canal para justificar la extralimitación estadounidense.

Washington muestra pocas señales de disminuir la presión sobre Panamá.

La competencia entre Estados Unidos y China no da señales de disminuir, mientras que Trump se ha impuesto como imperativo personal someter a China.

Estados Unidos está utilizando la dicotomía entre ambos países para debilitar fácilmente la autoridad de Panamá sobre el Canal.

En marzo, el Pentágono supuestamente contempló opciones militares para acceder al Canal, y Panamá demostró una firme determinación en la defensa de su autonomía territorial.

Trump ha demostrado una flagrante indiferencia hacia las sensibilidades panameñas al afirmar ante el Congreso que su administración "reclamará el Canal de Panamá, y ya hemos comenzado a hacerlo".

Esta línea de ataque le ha costado a Panamá algunos de sus intereses económicos con un socio asiático clave, en parte debido a los intentos de Washington por asegurarlo.

Las amenazas de Trump con el Canal no se refieren a la influencia china, sino a presionar a Panamá para que se asegure de seguir los dictados de Estados Unidos.

title: Consider the Lobster Tariffs: Trump’s Trade War Has Santa Barbara County’s Fishing and Ag Industries on Edge - (Published 9 hour(s), 0 minute(s) ago)
content: The vast majority of the lobster sold out of Central California grows in the cold waters of the Santa Barbara Channel and is exported live to Chinese markets. Lobster fishers are already worried about ...
resumen:
About 330,000 pounds of lobster lands at Santa Barbara's harbor each year. The vast majority of the lobster sold out of Central California grows in the cold waters of the Santa Barbara Channel and is exported live to Chinese markets. Lobster fishers are already worried about what the Trump tariffs will do to the market, once the season opens in October, said Chris Voss, president of the Santa Barbara Commercial Fishermen.

California State Treasurer Fiona Ma spoke on the tariffs’ impacts on consumers during a recent press call organized by Americans for Responsible Growth. About 330,000 pounds of lobster lands at Santa Barbara’s harbor, brought in by 45 fishers at an economic benefit of about $7 million last year, according to California Fish & Wildlife. Statewide, lobster represents a $24.2 million business. This time around felt like a repeat of the tariffs imposed during Trump’s first term, Voss said. Some workarounds were given for the economic loss back then, “but the scale of it now is so dramatic,” said Voss.

In a press call on Wednesday, Colorado’s Dave Young stressed that Trump’s chaotic and “reckless trade agenda has fueled uncertainty and fear across the globe, creating a self-inflicted crisis” that affected farmers’ and ranchers’ ability to buy machine parts and fertilizer. The treasurers of Minnesota and Illinois recalled the effect on soybeans during the previous Trump Administration’s tariffs, effectively switching China’s purchases to Brazil, a market loss from which domestic family farms were still recovering.

California’s state treasurer, Fiona Ma, emphasized the tariffs’ effects on consumers’ pocketbooks. On the day the tariffs were announced, she recalled, four truckloads of produce at the Mexican border were stuck until they paid the tariff. “This is what happened,” Ma said. “They charged their vendors; the vendors increased prices on the people. That’s how these tariffs work. They increase prices.”

Last week it was a 145 percent tariff, but on Tuesday, the White House had announced China faced up to a 245 percent tariff on imports to the U.S. It later had to explain that the number was a total of the tariffs since the first Trump Administration. China’s retaliatory tariff is a 125 percent tax on U.S. goods.

Wine, the county’s top finished agricultural product, was hit with an added 15 percent tariff in 2018, during Trump’s previous trade war with China. This time around, all U.S. goods, including wine, can expect a 125 percent tax to be applied as an entry duty to China.

In 2018 there was a big drop in exports, and then the COVID pandemic slowed things further, said JiaMin Dierberg, the director of international sales for Dierberg Vineyard, located in the Santa Rita Hills outside Buellton. According to the county Agricultural Commissioner’s office, among the items exported to China in 2023 were 5,275 empty wine barrels for liquor production and about 28 pounds of flower and vegetable seed. Santa Barbara County produces more than a million cases of wine annually, as well as selling nearly $1 billion in grapes for wines made across California.

Among Santa Barbara County’s chief exports are strawberries, and the county’s top export country is Canada. Canadian leaders agreed during a debate on Wednesday that they had stopped buying strawberries from the U.S. on principle.

content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent complained to President Trump that the acting commissioner had been installed without his knowledge.
resumen:
President Trump has replaced the acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service.

Michael Faulkender, Mr. Bessent’s deputy, will be the new acting leader, replacing Gary Shapley. Mr. Faulkender will be the third acting leader of the agency this week.

Mr. Bessent had complained to Mr. Trump that Mr. Musk had done an end run around him to get Mr. Shapley installed as the interim head of the I.R.S.

The position of I.R.S. commissioner will be filled in an acting capacity while former Representative Billy Long awaits Senate approval for the role.

Mr. Bessent praised Mr. Shapley for his “passion and thoughtfulness” and said that he remains an important adviser. Mr. Shapley and another I.R.S. critic of the Hunter Biden tax investigation, Joseph Ziegler, will be assigned to senior roles at the Treasury Department or the I.R.S.

Mr. Trump had picked Mr. Shapley to run the I.R.S. on Tuesday after the previous interim head, Melanie Krause, chose to resign. Ms. Krause quit after the Treasury Department agreed to use I.R.S. data to help Immigration and Customs Enforcement deport undocumented immigrants.

Mr. Musk has said he wants to donate another $100 million through political entities controlled by the president’s team.

As a special government employee, Mr. Musk is allotted 130 days of time on the job.

One of the DOGE members at the I.R.S., Gavin Kliger, was recently pushed out of the agency.

title: California manufacturing jobs, No. 1 in US, face trade war unknowns - (Published 10 hour(s), 49 minute(s) ago)
content: California also represents 10% of the nation’s 12.8 million manufacturing workforce, according to my trusty spreadsheet’s peek at various federal job stats. Texas was No. 2 with 973,600 jobs, followed ...
resumen:
America’s long-languishing factory jobs are a focal point of the Trump administration’s global tariff battles.

Last year, manufacturing employed 1.25 million statewide in California.

California also represents 10% of the nation’s 12.8 million manufacturing workforce.

Texas was No. 2 with 973,600 jobs, followed by Ohio with 683,800, Michigan with 605,600, and Illinois with 578,200.

Since 1995, the nation lost 4.5 million factory workers.

California dropped 468,200 factory workers over these three decades.

New York is down 394,400 jobs, North Carolina is off 363,300, and Ohio lost 353,800.

Eight states gained manufacturing work in this same period, topped by Utah’s 35,800 growth, Nevada, up 31,300, and Idaho adding 12,200.

The nation has lost 26% of its manufacturing jobs since 1995.

California’s down 27%.

Rhode Island lost half its manufacturing work, while New York is down 49%, and Massachusetts and North Carolina lost 44%.

Nevada had the biggest percentage gain, up 88% since 1995.

Then came North Dakota, up 43%, and Utah, up 31%.

California had 7% of its workers at factories last year, the 32nd highest share among the states.

Manufacturing was 8% of the 2024 U.S. job market.

Indiana had 16% of its jobs in manufacturing last year.

Wisconsin had 15%, Iowa had 14%, and Michigan and Alabama were at 13%.

California manufacturing is down from 14% of the job market three decades ago.

North Carolina factories employed 9% of all of the state’s workers last year – down from 24% in 1995.

Arkansas is down to 12% from 23% in 1995.

Mississippi is also at 12%, down from 22% three decades ago.

California factory work ranks No. 5 nationally with an average $30.51 hourly wage, 12% above the national average of $27.11.

The top four are Wyoming ($33.77), Colorado ($32.52), Washington state ($32.35), and Connecticut ($31.38).

Factory wages statewide are only 77% of the typical California worker’s $39.53 hourly rate in all industries.

Factories pay 79% of the average U.S. wage.

Manufacturing pays above or near the statewide norms in five states: Wyoming at 108%, Louisiana at 103%, Texas at 92%, Florida at 92%, and Kentucky at 90%.

title: Cinco regiones superan los US$ 900 millones en exportaciones al primer bimestre - (Published 15 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: ADEX informó que las exportaciones regionales crecieron 26.2% y sumaron US$ 10,298 millones hasta febrero. ¿Qué regiones lideraron los envíos al exterior?
resumen:
Las exportaciones de las regiones del Perú, sin considerar Lima y Callao, sumaron US$ 10,298 millones en los dos primeros meses de 2025, lo que representa un incremento de 26.2% respecto al mismo periodo del año anterior, según la Asociación de Exportadores (ADEX).

Del total exportado, US$ 8,104 millones correspondieron a productos tradicionales, con un aumento de 27.8%. El sector minero lideró con US$ 7,394 millones, un 26.7% más que en el mismo periodo del año pasado. También se registraron alzas en hidrocarburos (37.5%) y pesca primaria (117%). En contraste, los envíos agro tradicionales cayeron 40.2%.

Las exportaciones no tradicionales alcanzaron los US$ 2,194 millones, con un crecimiento de 20.7%. Este resultado estuvo impulsado principalmente por el rubro agroindustrial, que subió de US$ 1,319 millones a US$ 1,699 millones. Otros sectores como siderometalurgia (67.1%), metalmecánica (22.8%) y textil (1.3%) también mostraron aumentos. Sin embargo, seis de los diez rubros no tradicionales presentaron caídas, entre ellos madera (-14.6%), confecciones (-9.9%) y químico (-10.6%).

Ica encabezó el ranking regional con exportaciones por US$ 1,822 millones (7.8% más), principalmente por envíos de uvas, cobre y hierro. Le siguieron Arequipa (US$ 1,146 millones, +32%), Moquegua (US$ 1,103 millones, +34.3%) y Áncash (US$ 962 millones, +17.3%). Puno ocupó el quinto lugar con US$ 886 millones, registrando el mayor crecimiento porcentual (75.4%).

Otras regiones que destacaron por su fuerte expansión en valores relativos fueron Huánuco (443.8%), San Martín (130.7%), Junín (101.2%) y Ayacucho (85.3%).

En total, 19 regiones reportaron resultados positivos. Por el contrario, La Libertad, Cusco, Cajamarca y Huancavelica registraron caídas en sus exportaciones.

China, Estados Unidos, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, Canadá, Suiza e India fueron los principales mercados para los productos exportados desde las regiones.

title: Inmigración sí, economía no: las encuestas revelan el pensamiento de los estadounidenses sobre la gestión de Donald Trump - (Published 13 hour(s), 57 minute(s) ago)
content: Los votantes se muestran descontentos con los aranceles del presidente, pero a favor de las políticas migratorias.
resumen:
Según diversas encuestas recientes, la postura firme del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, frente a la inmigración continúa siendo una de sus cartas más fuertes ante el electorado. Sin embargo, sus políticas económicas, especialmente los aranceles comerciales, parecen estarle pasando factura.

Aproximadamente la mitad de los adultos en EE.UU. aprueban su enfoque migratorio, pero la mayoría cree que sus aranceles podrían dañar la economía nacional, tanto en el corto como en el largo plazo.

Una encuesta de AP-NORC revela que su índice de aprobación en temas migratorios supera al de su desempeño general como presidente.

Un estudio de Quinnipiac muestra que el 72% de los votantes considera que los aranceles impuestos por Trump perjudicarán la economía a corto plazo. Incluso entre los republicanos, un 44% comparte esta preocupación.

El presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, advirtió recientemente que las medidas arancelarias podrían acelerar la inflación y frenar el crecimiento económico.

De acuerdo con una encuesta de YouGov/Economist, la aprobación de Trump entre los jóvenes cayó de +5 al inicio de su presidencia a -29 en la actualidad.

Solo 4 de cada 10 adultos aprueban su manejo de la presidencia, según la encuesta de AP-NORC.

title: Ford pauses shipments SUVs, sports cars and other models to China - (Published 12 hour(s), 1 minute(s) ago)
content: Ford has halted exports of key US-built vehicles to China amid rising tariffs and trade tensions, impacting a once-profitable segment of its business, WSJ reports. Engine shipments continue.
resumen:
Ford ha suspendido las exportaciones de sus SUV, camionetas y autos deportivos a China debido a los aranceles de represalia impuestos en medio de las tensiones comerciales en curso bajo el expresidente Donald Trump, según informó el Wall Street Journal el viernes.

Esta semana, el fabricante de automóviles detuvo los envíos de sus F-150 Raptors, Mustangs, Bronco SUV fabricados en Michigan y Lincoln Navigators fabricados en Kentucky al mercado chino, según informes.

Ford dijo en un comunicado: "Hemos ajustado las exportaciones de EE. UU. a China a la luz de los aranceles actuales".

La pausa en la exportación se atribuye a la escalada de los aranceles, con China apuntando a las importaciones de vehículos estadounidenses en respuesta a las medidas comerciales de EE. UU.

Según el WSJ, el negocio de exportación a China representa una operación pequeña pero rentable para Ford.

La compañía ganó aproximadamente $900 millones en ganancias operativas de sus operaciones en China el año pasado, dijo el vicepresidente de Ford, John Lawler, en una conferencia reciente.

Se espera que las exportaciones de Ford de motores y transmisiones fabricados en EE. UU. a China continúen a pesar de la pausa en las exportaciones de vehículos ensamblados.

También se espera que su modelo Lincoln Nautilus, que se fabrica en China, continúe con los envíos, a pesar de los fuertes aranceles.

En 2024, Ford envió alrededor de 5,500 Broncos, F-150, Mustangs y Navigators a China, una fuerte disminución del promedio anual de más de 20,000 vehículos enviados en la última década.

resumen:
El banano peruano tuvo un crecimiento de 8% en volumen el año pasado. Las exportaciones peruanas de banano bordearon las 39,689 toneladas, con un valor cercano a los US$ 34 millones y representando una caída del 12% en volumen y del 9% en valor, en el primer trimestre.
Esto se explicó por problemas como la escasez hídrica en Piura acontecida a fines del 2024, que redujo varias hectáreas cultivadas en el valle del Chira.
La fragmentación de la producción en el norte, sumada a la falta de grandes distribuidores, ha debilitado el poder de negociación de los pequeños productores, limitando su rentabilidad.
La demanda se ha mantenido baja y la competencia con países como Ecuador se ha intensificado.
Sumaron como factores los crecientes costos de producción y logística.
El problema se agrava por los recurrentes problemas hídricos en Piura (87% de la producción) y Lambayeque (8%).
El precio promedio por kilogramo se incrementó ligeramente a US$ 0.87, un 3% más que en el mismo periodo del año anterior.
Estados Unidos —segundo mayor destino de este producto— anunció un gravamen del 10% que, de aplicarse, reduciría volúmenes y rentabilidad.
Se proyecta que los volúmenes no superarán los del 2024.
Se estima una caída de entre el 2% y el 7% al cierre del año.
Europa se mantiene como el principal destino del banano peruano, sumando 23,392 toneladas enviadas durante el último trimestre, por un valor aproximado de US$ 19 millones, lo que representó una disminución del 16% en volumen y del 15% en valor.
Los principales competidores son Ecuador, Costa Rica y Panamá.
El segundo mercado clave es Estados Unidos, con aproximadamente 8,137 toneladas exportadas y un valor cercano a los US$ 8 millones.
En este destino, la caída en volumen fue más moderada (alrededor del 5%) e incluso se registró un ligero incremento del 2% en el valor exportado.

title: Meloni and Trump: Oval Office Meeting Cements Special Rapport - (Published 17 hour(s), 46 minute(s) ago)
content: In Washington, President Trump lavished praise on Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy. He also accepted her invitation to visit Rome.
resumen:
Para los líderes internacionales, visitar la Casa Blanca en estos días es una empresa impredecible que conlleva el riesgo de ser avergonzado o, peor aún, reprendido por el presidente Trump. Para la primera ministra de Italia, Giorgia Meloni, la reunión del jueves en el Despacho Oval fue en gran medida un asunto tranquilo, con el Sr. Trump cubriéndola de elogios hiperbólicos y dejando claro que le tiene cariño.

Más allá de las bromas amistosas contra la inmigración y el optimismo compartido de que la Unión Europea y Estados Unidos llegarían a un acuerdo comercial, ninguno de los líderes indicó que hubieran logrado avances sustanciales en las negociaciones sobre aranceles y otros temas.

"No tenemos prisa", dijo el Sr. Trump.

La Sra. Meloni fue la primera líder europea en visitar la Casa Blanca desde que el Sr. Trump impuso y luego pausó parcialmente aranceles generalizados contra la Unión Europea. La reunión disipó cualquier duda restante sobre la relación especial entre los dos líderes. Pero lo que la relación podría producir para Italia y para Europa seguía sin estar claro.

"Fue tratada como una aliada de primer rango", dijo Lorenzo Castellani, politólogo de la Universidad Luiss Guido Carli de Roma, y agregó que era inusual para Italia, que no es una potencia militar o económica.

"Se convirtió en una mediadora de facto", dijo, "pero en términos concretos, no se llevó nada a casa".

La política comercial de los países europeos se lleva a cabo colectivamente a través de la Unión Europea, y la Sra. Meloni dejó claro que no podía buscar un acuerdo en nombre del bloque. Quizás su mayor logro: el Sr. Trump aceptó su invitación para una visita en el "futuro cercano" a Roma, donde esperaba que se reuniera con funcionarios europeos.

Si eso sucede, podría ayudar a consolidar su posición como conducto entre Europa y Washington. Por ahora, sin embargo, como dijo, el Sr. Trump no había ofrecido ninguna garantía de que se reuniría con funcionarios europeos.

La Sra. Meloni buscó vincularse con el Sr. Trump por su aversión tanto a la ideología que consideran "despierta" como a las políticas de diversidad, equidad e inclusión. También se comprometió a aumentar las importaciones de gas estadounidense y reforzar el gasto militar, elementos clave de la agenda del Sr. Trump. Descartó una pregunta sobre el desprecio del Sr. Trump por Europa como "un parásito" que vive de Estados Unidos.

"¿Alguna vez has dicho eso?", le preguntó al presidente. "Nunca dijo eso".

El viernes, en Roma, la Sra. Meloni volvió a enfatizar la relación entre Estados Unidos y Europa, describiéndola como "privilegiada" cuando se reunió con el vicepresidente JD Vance, quien viajó allí para la Pascua.

Cuando se reunió con el Sr. Trump, no, como algunos temían que lo hiciera, le dio la espalda a Ucrania, repitiendo su posición de que "el invasor era Putin y Rusia".

El jueves, en París, el presidente Emmanuel Macron de Francia, que también ha establecido una relación de cooperación con el Sr. Trump a pesar de mayores diferencias ideológicas, mantuvo conversaciones con funcionarios estadounidenses sobre la guerra. Después de la reunión, el secretario de Estado Marco Rubio dijo que Estados Unidos abandonaría los esfuerzos para poner fin a la guerra en Ucrania si resulta imposible lograr un progreso significativo en los próximos días.

En su reunión con la Sra. Meloni, el Sr. Trump dijo que "Europa es muy importante para mí" y que quería que "a Europa le fuera muy bien", una diferencia de tono de cuando dijo que la Unión Europea fue creada para "joder" a Estados Unidos.

Los fanáticos de la Sra. Meloni acreditaron a la primera ministra.

Carlo Fidanza, jefe de la delegación de la Sra. Meloni en el Parlamento Europeo, calificó la reunión como "la primera vez que Trump se pone tan claramente a disposición de un acuerdo con la Unión Europea". Eso, dijo, "se lo debemos" a la Sra. Meloni.

Pero incluso cuando el Sr. Trump se sentó junto a la Sra. Meloni y la llamó amiga, afirmó su intención de imponer enérgicamente aranceles a sus socios comerciales.

"Todo el mundo quiere llegar a un acuerdo y si no quieren llegar a un acuerdo, haremos el acuerdo por ellos", dijo el Sr. Trump.

"Somos los que realmente establecemos el trato", agregó, "y eso es lo que haremos".

Los críticos de la Sra. Meloni la instaron a convertir las amabilidades en concesiones reales.

"Grandes sonrisas en la Casa Blanca: esperamos que nuestras empresas también puedan volver a sonreír", dijo Matteo Renzi, ex primer ministro de Italia y político de la oposición, en un comunicado. "Para ellos, por el momento, los aranceles y la incertidumbre permanecen".

En Bruselas, los funcionarios, los grupos de consumidores y los políticos han pasado semanas tratando de averiguar si la administración Trump está realmente interesada en llegar a un acuerdo, y se han quedado con poca claridad. La mayor parte del tiempo, dicen los funcionarios europeos, ni siquiera saben si están hablando con las personas adecuadas en la administración mientras intentan negociar.

Lo que suceda a continuación "depende de Estados Unidos", dijo Léa Auffret, jefa de asuntos internacionales de BEUC, la Organización Europea de Consumidores.

En Italia, la calidez del Sr. Trump hacia la Sra. Meloni la ayudó en su rivalidad con los socios de la coalición a su derecha, incluido el líder del partido de extrema derecha Liga, Matteo Salvini, que han cortejado al Sr. Trump y sus aliados, dijeron los expertos.

"A nivel nacional, fue un buen éxito", dijo Enzo Moavero Milanesi, ex ministro de Relaciones Exteriores italiano. "Para Europa: Ya veremos".

title: Perú con 10% de aranceles de Trump: el impacto que no se calcula de manera directa - (Published 21 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Voceros del sector público y privado coinciden en la estimación de pérdida si se ejecuta la medida económica que planea el presidente de Estados Unidos.
resumen:
Los aranceles que Donald Trump, el presidente de Estados Unidos, planea disponer para sus socios comerciales mantienen en vilo al Perú. Hay un 10% latente que amenaza a las exportaciones de este país.

Pedro Herrera, director general de Asuntos de Economía Internacional, Competitividad y Productividad del MEF, simuló el impacto monetario que se evidenciaría en el Perú de aprobarse el 10% de aranceles. El costo anual sería de US$ 705 millones, con un valor exportado estimado de US$ 7,045 millones.

El sector productivo más afectado sería, en primer lugar, el Agropecuario. Continúan las Artesanías, Maderas y papeles, Metal-mecánico y Minería no metálica. Los más afectados serían las uvas y los arándanos. De cada 10 empresas exportadoras a Estados Unidos, 6 son mipymes.

Jaime Dupuy, director ejecutivo de Comex Perú, coincidió con esta idea. Ambos destacaron que la retaliación es una medida perjudicial.

Las represalias comerciales aplicadas entre 2018 y 2019 por socios comerciales de Estados Unidos generaron pérdidas en la exportación de bienes agrícolas para China, México, Canadá, la Unión Europea, Turquía y la India de US$ 25,7 mil millones, US$ 500 millones, US$ 100 millones, US$ 600 millones, US$ 100 millones y US$ 100 millones, respectivamente.

Los países que no tomaron represalias comerciales durante el primer gobierno de Trump —como Sudáfrica, Argentina y Brasil— se adaptaron al aumento de la demanda de los países que reorientaron sus relaciones comerciales.

Herrera y Dupuy también identificaron los factores que no se visualizan en términos numéricos, pero que se distinguen como posibles daños ante la dinámica de exportación.

title: Keir Starmer y Donald Trump continúan las negociaciones por un acuerdo comercial “libre y abierto” entre Estados Unidos y Reino Unido - (Published 8 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: Los mandatarios han entablado diálogos pacíficos y constructivos, con miras a encontrar una solución diplomática a la política arancelaria de la Casa Blanca ...
resumen:
El presidente Donald Trump y el primer ministro británico, Keir Starmer, insistieron este viernes en la necesidad de alcanzar un acuerdo que permita el comercio “libre y abierto” entre sus países, en medio de la política arancelaria impulsada por la Casa Blanca.

Los mandatarios mantuvieron una llamada telefónica este mañana en la que avanzaron en las “conversaciones productivas y en curso entre el Reino Unido y Estados Unidos en materia de comercio”, con el foco puesto en un esquema justo para ambos y en la “protección del interés nacional”, informó Downing Street en un comunicado.

Starmer buscará una solución pacífica, siempre y cuando se alinee con el interés nacional y la estabilidad económica a los británicos.

“El Reino Unido está trabajando con Estados Unidos en un acuerdo de prosperidad económica, basándose en la fuerza compartida de nuestro compromiso con la seguridad económica. Como parte de esas conversaciones, el Primer Ministro y el presidente Trump analizaron los avances logrados”, sumó el Ejecutivo londinense.

En febrero, Starmer estuvo en el Despacho Oval y, para septiembre, se prevé la visita del republicano a Downing Street.

title: U.S. tariffs could cost Germany 290 bln euros: report - (Published 13 hour(s), 54 minute(s) ago)
content: BERLIN, April 18 (Xinhua) -- U.S. tariffs could slash Germany's economic output by as much as 290 billion euros (330 billion U.S. dollars) over four years, the German Economic Institute (IW) has ...
resumen: U.S. tariffs could slash Germany's economic output by as much as 290 billion euros (330 billion U.S. dollars) over four years, the German Economic Institute (IW) has warned, projecting an annual GDP loss of 1.6 percent for Europe's largest economy by 2028. The report analyzes the potential fallout from the "reciprocal tariffs" announced by U.S. President Donald Trump on April 2, which would impose an additional 20 percent duty on imports from the European Union (EU), among other trading partners, citing large trade deficits. According to the IW, Germany's direct losses from these measures could reach 200 billion euros, or 1.2 percent of GDP annually by 2028. With retaliatory responses factored in, total damages may rise to 290 billion euros. The EU as a whole could face cumulative losses of up to 1.1 trillion euros by 2028, the report estimated. Germany, a highly export-oriented economy, has posted a trade surplus with the United States for 33 consecutive years. In 2024, this surplus reached a record 69.8 billion euros. Data from Germany's statistical authorities showed that the United States accounted for 10.4 percent of Germany's total exports last year, the highest share since 2002. The IW urged the EU to respond decisively, suggesting that retaliation could extend beyond goods to include U.S. digital firms and other service sectors. (1 euro = 1.14 U.S. dollar)

title: Extreme uncertainty sends tremors through central banks and multilateral organizations - (Published 21 hour(s), 28 minute(s) ago)
content: The IMF revises global economic forecasts downwards due to Trump’s trade war while the ECB cuts interest rates for the sixth time ...
resumen:
The ramping up of global trade tensions has become a central issue for central banks and multilateral organizations. Institutions such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, the World Trade Organization (WTO) and central banks have begun to revise their growth projections and redesign policies. The international economic playbook now has less predictable rules. The WTO is warning of an increasingly fragmented environment that threatens to blur the frameworks of global cooperation and to undermine the exchange of goods and economic growth.

The IMF announced on April 17 that there would be a wave of “significant downgrades” in the growth projections of many countries. The fund rules out a recession, but does insist there will be hikes in inflation forecasts.

IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that prolonged uncertainty raises the risk of tensions in financial markets. World Bank president Ajay Banga warned that greater uncertainty and economic instability will weigh down the world economy.

After declaring a universal general tariff of 10% and additional rates for countries with which the U.S. has a larger trade deficit, Trump announced a 90-day pause to negotiate with nearly 70 governments. The only one not spared from the armistice is China.

Spain’s Economy Minister Carlos Cuerpo met with U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. There was also a meeting between Japan and the U.S., in which no agreement was reached. April 17 saw Trump hobnob with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni.

The European Central Bank (ECB) cut rates for the sixth consecutive time, to 2.25%, in an attempt to counteract the negative economic impact of the tariffs. ECB President Christine Lagarde has acknowledged that the overall picture is being shaped by “exceptional uncertainty” and that the increase in tariff disputes threatens to further dampen exports.

All markets fell after the rate cut. The Ibex 35 closed 0.19% down, the German Dax fell by 0.53%, while the French stock market and the Euro Stoxx 50 fell by more than 0.6%. The Italian Mib, for its part, limited losses to 0.24%.

The Federal Reserve is being more cautious with rate cuts. Its chairman, Jerome Powell, has insisted on the inflationary risks of the tariffs imposed by the White House.

The WTO has cut its growth forecast for trade in goods by almost three points, from an initial increase of 2.7% to a fall of 0.2% by 2025. If the tariff offensive intensifies, the decline would be 1.5% this year and the global economy could fall by 7% in the long term.
